To view the orientation of robtargets in angles, select the Show quaternions as RPY angles checkbox in the RAPID Data Editor. Orientations can be represented in angles and quaternions, set the default representation in the RobotStudio Options.

wrapper.paragraph: The RAPID Data Editor only shows data declarations that contain editable values.

section.title: Creating custom instructions using Instruction Template

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: RobotStudio provides certain set of default instructions. To create instructions for custom applications such as paint, dispensing etc, the Instruction Template feature can be used. You can manually define the instruction templates for RAPID motion instructions other than the default instructions such as MoveL, and MoveC. Custom instructions created using the instruction template feature can be saved as template files and shared with other PCs.

The instruction templates can be saved in the C:\Users\<user name>\Documents\RobotStudio\Instruction Templates in XML format and reused later. These files can be used in the same way as any other pre-defined XML files that are imported and used for robot controllers with appropriate RobotWare options.

listitem.paragraph: Create a custom procedure which accepts arguments such as robtarget, tooldata, and an optional wobjdata as move instructions.
The procedure can include additional arguments such as speeddata and zonedata or other process related parameters.
Example 1

wrapper.paragraph: PROC MyMoveL(robtarget ToPoint, PERS tooldata Tool,\wobjdata Wobj)
MoveL ToPoint,v100,fine,Tool,\Wobj:=wobj0;
ENDPROC

listitem.paragraph: Example 2

wrapper.paragraph: PROC MyMoveJ(robtarget ToPoint, PERS tooldata Tool,\wobjdata Wobj)
MoveJ ToPoint,v100,fine,Tool,\Wobj:=wobj0;
ENDPROC

It is helpful to use the standard naming convention for arguments and instructions. The last letter of the instruction defines the type of the instruction, for example, MoveL implies linear movement, similarly, MoveC and MoveJ implies, circular and joint movements respectively. Following naming conventions helps RobotStudio to interpret the instructions faster, which reduces user input while defining the instruction template. The robtarget must be named ToPoint, incase of circular instruction the via point must be named ViaPoint according to the naming convention.

listitem.paragraph: Open Instruction Template window.
In the Instruction Template window, select the instruction and then click the Add button.

Repeat this step for all instructions. The instructions are grouped according to the process name (for example, MyMove). Adjustments to the Motion Type, Point Mapping and default parameters are possible at this phase as required.
Motion type defines how RobotStudio traces the path preview. Point Mapping defines how RobotStudio interprets robtarget.
Select the new instruction templates and then click Export Selection button and then the Save button to save the file as XML in the Instruction Template folder.

The instruction template file must be exported for sharing the file with other users or for using it in the RAPID Path editor. To export the file, use the Export Selection button. Import this file to the PC for using it in a station.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Use RAPID Path editor to graphically view and edit programs loaded into a controller. The RAPID program is displayed in a 3D structure in the RAPID Path Editor that allows editing of multiple robtargets. The edits made in the graphical RAPID program gets updated in the corresponding RAPID Editor and the RAPID Data Editor simultaneously.

wrapper.title: Using the RAPID Path Editor
wrapper.paragraph: In the RAPID tab, right-click the Module or the Path to open the RAPID Path Editor and the Properties window. Select any target in the RAPID Editor and the corresponding visualization gets displayed in the RAPID Path editor. Any change in the position of a target using the freehand tool in the RAPID Path Editor, gets reflected in the corresponding RAPID program. Also its properties change to the new position of the target.

listitem.paragraph: Editing target definition: Use Properties tab to edit target definition such as position, orientation and external axes.
Editing move instruction: Edit a move instruction using the Properties tab that includes the values for arguments.
Editing a Jointtarget: Edit the joint values in a Jointtarget using the external Axes in the Properties tab. However, a jointtarget has no corresponding graphical representation.

wrapper.paragraph: Changes to the graphical representation of the RAPID program gets reflected in the Properties tab and vice-versa.

wrapper.title: Using the Path Editor tab
wrapper.paragraph: Use the RAPID Path Editor tab to import a work piece or a tool to the graphical representation of the RAPID program.

listitem.paragraph: Importing a work piece: To visualize a work piece in the Path editor, import it from a geometry or library file.
To set the position of the imported work piece, click Set position or choose a wobj from the list of wobj defined in the program.
Importing a tool: Add a tool to the visualization by using the tool option. Import a tool from ABB library or user library (.rslib).

wrapper.title: Creating custom move instructions in the path editor.
wrapper.paragraph: RAPID Path Editor supports generic move instructions. It is possible to view and create such move instructions in the 3D environment of a robot station and in the RAPID Path Editor. The following procedure describes how to view an instruction template file in the RAPID Path Editor.
The required instruction template file must be imported to the host PC before starting this procedure.

listitem.paragraph: Copy the required instruction template file to the C:\Users\<user name>\Documents\RobotStudio\Instruction Templates folder in the computer.
The search path depends on how the RobotStudio documents folder is configured.
Open the RAPID Path Editor to view and edit the custom move instruction in RobotStudio like a standard move instruction.

wrapper.title: Applying and verifying the edits
wrapper.paragraph: To apply the changes made in the editor to the virtual controller and also to check the program, In RAPID tab, go to the Controller group, and click the arrow next to the Apply icon, perform any of the following steps:

listitem.paragraph: To apply only the changes made in the module, currently displayed in the editor, click Apply Changes.
Alternatively, click the Apply icon
To apply the changes made in all modified modules, click Apply All.

wrapper.paragraph: The Apply commands are enabled only for unsaved changes. RobotStudio commits the changes without losing the program pointer. If this is not possible, you will be asked if it is OK to lose the program pointer.
To verify the syntactic and semantic correctness of the modules, in the Test and Debug group, click Check Program.

wrapper.title: Synchronizing to station
wrapper.paragraph: Synchronize the virtual controller to station for applying the changes performed on the RAPID program to the virtual station. This applies to virtual robots only.
Synchronize to station is available only for the virtual controller.

listitem.paragraph: On the RAPID tab, in the Access group, click the arrow next to the Synchronize icon, and then click Synchronize to Station.
Select the paths to be synchronized to the station from the list.
Click OK.
The message Synchronization to Station completed is displayed in the Output window.

wrapper.paragraph: RAPID can be synchronized from the files of the HOME folder as an alternative:

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller browser, under Home folder, right-click any file and then click Synchronize to Station to synchronize data and procedures of the selected file into the station.
In the Controller browser, under Home folder, right-click any file and then click Synchronize to File to synchronize data and procedures from the station into the selected file.
Before selecting this option, you must synchronize the selected file to the station. Using the Synchronize to File option can conflict with the synchronize to RAPID option.
Robtargets that are local to a procedure are not supported by Synchronize to Station. Only robtargets that are local to a module are supported.

RobotStudio does not fully support instructions using Offs or RelTool functions. These are synchronized and will appear in the element browser, but commands such as View Tool at Target and Locate Target will not work. Targets used in the instructions will not be visible in graphics. However, instructions can be programmed and edited using the RAPID Editor and can be simulated using the virtual controller.
RobotStudio does not support RAPID programs containing arrays of tooldata, robtargets and workobjects. These programs will not be synchronized to the station.

Workobjects and tooldata that are shared between several tasks must be specified in RAPID with its full value for each task when programming offline with RobotStudio. This will trigger a warning Initial value for PERS not updated in the controller event log. You may ignore this warning. However, ensure that the RAPID variable definitions are the same in all tasks, otherwise you may get unexpected behavior.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: World Zone is a defined programmed zone within a station. When using world zones, the robot stops or an output is automatically set if the robot is inside the user-defined area.
World Zones are used for the following purposes:

listitem.paragraph: To indicate that the tool center point is in a specific part of the working area.
To limit the working area of the robot in order to avoid collision with the tool.
To make a common work area for two robots available to only one robot at a time.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The following RobotWare options must be selected while creating the virtual controller.

listitem.paragraph: For RobotWare 6, select 608-1 World Zones.
For RobotWare 7, select 3106-1 World Zones.

wrapper.title: Procedure
wrapper.paragraph: World Zone instructions can be visualized and synchronized between the Station and virtual controller. The instructions for defining World Zone volumes (WZBoxDef, WZCylDef and WZSphDef) are visualized as semi-transparent shapes in the Station environment. It is possible to set the color of the shapes or hide them.
Use the following steps to visualize World Zone.

listitem.paragraph: Create a virtual controller with the respective RobotWare option.
Open the station, and then open the RAPID Editor. Add the following shapedata variables for box, cylinder and sphere under Module1.

Refer to the
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
3HAC065040-001
for more information.
Add the following in the main().
Visualization requires the instructions to use numeric literals in the volume definition.
In the Controller group, click Apply and then click Synchronize and click Synchronize to Station...
In the Synchronize to Station.. dialog, click main and then click OK.
World zone shapes Box, Sphere and Cylinder appear in the graphics view. The instructions are visible in Paths& targets Tree view as action instructions.
To edit the world zone instructions, in the Paths& targets browser, right-click the instruction and then click Edit Instruction...
In the Edit Instruction... browser, edit the required variable and then click Apply to view the changes.

wrapper.paragraph: If a virtual controller is created with the World Zones option, the instruction templates are imported automatically. If this option is added after creating the virtual controller, the instruction templates must be imported manually. To add instruction templates manually:

listitem.paragraph: Open the Edit Instruction Templates window. Click Import.
Browse the Instruction Templates folder and select WorldZones.xml file and then click Open. The World Zone instructions are added to the instructions list in the Edit Instruction Templates window.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph:
Visualizing World Zones that are defined in joint coordinates ( WZLimJointDef and WZHomeJointDef
) are not supported.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Debugging involves locating and correcting code errors in a task. Debugging is part of the code testing and is an integral part of the entire software development. RAPID editor provides several debugging features for testing and perfecting your code. Some of them are introducing breakpoints for tracking a particular instruction, using call stack window to monitor program pointer and so on.

wrapper.title: Selecting, Starting and stopping a task for RobotWare 6.xx
wrapper.paragraph: A task can be selected, started, and stopped from the RAPID editor:

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller group, click the Selected tasks button to view the list of tasks. You can select the required foreground task(Normal) or background task (Semistatic/Static) from the list.
In the Controller group, click the Start button to start executing the selected task.
In the Controller group, click the Stop button to stop executing the selected task.

wrapper.paragraph: You can monitor the status of execution in the Output window.

wrapper.title: Task execution state for RobotWare 5.xx and 6.xx
wrapper.paragraph: A task can be activated, started, and stopped from the Controller browser with the following limitations:

listitem.paragraph: Motors must be in ON state for the Start operation.
Need Write access to the controller and the grants Execute program or Full access. While performing Start or Stop operations in Auto, the Remote Start Stop in Auto grant is required.
Normal tasks alone can be activated and deactivated. Background tasks are activated automatically.
Background tasks of type Static and Semistatic with the TrustLevel set to NoSafety only can be started and stopped.
For detailed information about the different TrustLevel values, see the Technical reference manual - system parameters.

wrapper.paragraph: The following table shows cases where task execution state cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Activating, starting and stopping tasks in RobotWare 5.xx
wrapper.paragraph: To activate a task, right-click the task in the Controller browser and then turn on the Active command. If the prerequisites are met, you can operate the task, such as start and stop the task, move the Program Pointer to main and set the run mode.

To start a task, right-click the task in the Controller browser and then click Start Task. You can start Normal tasks, but you can only start a Static or Semistatic task if the TrustLevel is set to NoSafety.
When starting a task, the manipulator axes may move very quickly and sometimes in unexpected ways! Make sure no personnel is near the manipulator arm!

To stop a task, right-click the task in the Controller browser and then click Stop Task. You can stop Normal tasks, but to stop a Static or Semistatic task the TrustLevel must be set to NoSafety. This method of starting and stopping tasks is applicable only for RobotWare version 5.15.xx and below.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: RAPID instructions are executed in the controller for carrying out various operations. These instructions are grouped into various tasks and these tasks are further grouped into motion and non-motion tasks. A non-motion task affects a logical part of the controller operation such as handling of signals, whereas a motion task controls the movement of a mechanical equipment, for example, a manipulator.

A task is a collection of RAPID instructions that are executed line by line. Every task has a program pointer. During execution, program pointer points to the current line of code in a task. The program pointer indicates the instruction with which the program will start execution or rather the program execution continues from the instruction where the program pointer is located.

The motion pointer indicates the instruction of the motion task that the robot is currently executing. A motion task has both motion pointer and program pointer. Program pointer is ahead of the motion pointer for preparing the controller for motion execution. A motion pointer is normally located at one or more instructions after the program pointer. This allows the system to execute and calculate the robot path faster before the robot moves. The motion pointer is represented as a small robot icon placed to the left margin in the RAPID Editor.

A task can further be classified into, Normal, Static and Semistatic. A motion task must always be Normal. But a non-motion task can be Normal, Static or Semistatic. Execution of Static and Semistatic tasks start when the controller is powered on. But a Normal task start only when the Play button is pressed. In a Semistatic task, when the controller restarts, the program execution starts from the beginning of the task. But the program execution of a Static task starts from the last position of the program pointer before restart.

wrapper.title: How the program pointer helps
wrapper.paragraph: During program execution, the program pointer points to the line of code that is currently executing. The function Follow Program Pointer keeps the program pointer visible during program execution by automatically scrolling the RAPID editor window according to the movements of the program pointer. To enable the function, in the Test and Debug group on the RAPID tab, click the arrow next to the program pointer icon and then select Follow Program Pointer.
During program execution, you can view the movement of program pointer across all open modules. Hence, keep all required modules open.
The other commands in the Program Pointer menu are:

listitem.paragraph: Go To Program Pointer â To show the current location of the program pointer in the RAPID editor
Go To Motion Pointer â To show the current location of the motion pointer in the RAPID editor

To set the program pointer at a particular line of code or code segment and then start program execution from that point, use the Set Program Pointer options. You can choose from the following options:
Set Program Pointer to Main in all tasks
Set Program Pointer to Cursor
Set Program Pointer to Routine

wrapper.title: Maintaining the program pointer
wrapper.paragraph: The RAPID code can only be edited when the controller is not running, that is when it is in state Ready or Stopped. In Ready state the program pointer is not set, but in Stopped state the program pointer is set to a specific location of the program. For limited changes to the RAPID code of a controller in Stopped state, the current location of the program pointer can be maintained. After such an edit, you can resume program execution from where it was without having to reset the program pointer.
If the edit is too large for the program pointer to be maintained then a warning message is displayed to convey this.

The program pointer cannot be maintained, for example, when editing the line of code at which the program pointer is located. Editing that line of code results in resetting the program pointer. In effect, the program will start from the beginning when the controller is started after the edit.
After resetting program pointer, when the program execution starts, the robot can move along the shortest path from its current location to the first point of the program.

wrapper.title: Using breakpoints
wrapper.paragraph: Breakpoints are used to stop program execution at a certain point or line of code. Set breakpoints to stop program execution to monitor the state of code variables or to view the call stack. You can set a breakpoint in the source code by clicking in the left margin of a file. When you run this code, execution stops whenever the breakpoint is hit, that is, before the code on that line is executed. Press the Start button to resume execution.

When a RAPID program is run from RobotStudio using the Play button, the program execution includes breakpoints and stops execution at breakpoints. Breakpoint functionality is available only in RobotStudio. When the program is run from FlexPendant, breakpoints are ignored. Breakpoints can be viewed in the RAPID Breakpoints window. Double-click a certain breakpoint to view the particular line of code.

section.title: Navigate through your program using RAPID Call Stack window

wrapper.title: Using the Call Stack window
wrapper.paragraph: A call stack stores information about the active subroutines of a RAPID program. Use the Call Stack window to view the routine call currently on the stack. This feature is useful especially for tracking program pointer during the execution of nested routines.
The following example shows a nested routine where Procedure 1 calls Procedure 2 which then calls Procedure 3 and so on. The Call Stack window tracks program pointer and shows the trail of execution.

The Call Stack window displays the name of the task, module, routine and line number that shows the trail of program pointer during program execution. Call Stack will not be refreshed automatically during program execution, and it gets refreshed automatically when the execution completes. To refresh call stack during program execution, click the Refresh button.

section.title: Using RAPID Watch window for debugging your RAPID code

wrapper.title: Viewing variables and I/O signals
wrapper.paragraph: The RAPID Watch window displays details such as name, value, datatype and system name of selected variables and I/O signals during program execution. You can view and edit RAPID data of variables in the RAPID watch window, during program execution and after the controller stops. I/O signals can only be viewed and not edited in the RAPID watch window. To view a variable or I/O signal in the RAPID watch window, it must be added to the window. In the RAPID editor, right-click the required variable or I/O signal, and then click Add Watch.

By default, during program execution, values of variables are automatically refreshed in the RAPID watch window every 2 seconds. You can also manually refresh these values. To enable or disable automatic refresh, in the context menu, select or clear the Auto Refresh command. To do a manual refresh, in the context menu, click Refresh (keyboard shortcut F5).
CONST variables cannot be edited. Variables and signals added to the RAPID watch window gets removed when RobotStudio closes.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The Simulation Setup dialog box is used to perform the following two main tasks.

listitem.paragraph: Setting up the sequence and entry point in the robot program.
Creating simulation scenarios for different simulated objects.

wrapper.paragraph: You can create simulation scenarios containing different simulated objects and connect each scenario with a predefined state to ensure that the correct state is applied to all project objects before running the scenario. If you want to simulate a specific part or segment of the cell where not all simulated objects in the cell are included, you can set up a new scenario and add only the objects needed for simulation.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: To set up a simulation, the following conditions must be met:

listitem.paragraph: At least one path must have been created in the station.
The paths to be simulated must be synchronized to the virtual controller.

wrapper.title: Setup simulation pane
wrapper.paragraph: From this pane, you can perform the combined task of configuring the program sequence and program execution such as entry point, and running the execution mode.
The Setup simulation pane consists of the following:

listitem.paragraph: Add: Click to add a new scenario.
Remove: Click to delete the selected scenario.
Rename: Click to rename the selected scenario.

td.paragraph: Displays all objects that can be part of a simulation. Objects that utilize simulation time can be part of a simulation. For example, virtual controllers and Smart Components. When you create a new scenario, all objects are selected by default.

listitem.paragraph: Time slice: This option makes RobotStudio always use the time slice mode.
Free run: This option makes RobotStudio always use the free run mode.
Click Simulation Setup to bring up the Simulation Setup pane.
Select the tasks to be active during simulation in the Select Active Tasks box.
Select the run mode as either Continuous or Single Cycle.
From the Simulated Objects list select the task.
Select the entry point from the Entry point list.
Click Edit to open the RAPID program where the user can edit the procedure.

wrapper.title: Creating simulation scenarios
wrapper.paragraph: Verify the productivity of certain solutions, check collision in robot cell, ensure that robot program is free of any motion error.

listitem.paragraph: Click Simulation Setup to bring up the Setup Simulation pane.
Under Active Simulation Scenario ,
Click Add to create a new scenario in the Simulated objects box.
Click Remove to delete the selected scenario from the Simulated objects box.
Select a saved state for the scenario from the Initial state list.
In the Simulation Control group,
The Pause button is enabled once you start the simulation.
The Play button is changed to Resume once you pause the simulation.
Click Resume to resume the simulation.

td.paragraph: Play and select Record to Viewer
Start the simulation and to record it to a Export Viewer.
The Save As dialog box appears where the simulation is saved.

listitem.paragraph: The Pause button is changed to Step once you start the simulation.
Click Step to run the simulation in steps.

td.paragraph: You can set the simulation time step.
Reset the simulation to its initial state.

wrapper.paragraph: When running a simulation in time slice mode, all breakpoints set in the RAPID editor windows will be deactivated temporarily.

During the simulation play, if a user does not want more objects to be added to the conveyor, in Layout browser, expand the conveyor node, then right-click the object source and clear the Enabled option.

listitem.paragraph: In the Simulation Control group, click Reset to reset the simulation.
Click Reset and select Save Current state to store states of objects and virtual controllers to be used in a simulation scenario.
Click Reset and select Manage states to start Station Logic.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: With RobotStudio you can detect and log collisions between objects in the station. The basic concepts of collision detection are explained below.

wrapper.title: Collision sets collision sets
wrapper.paragraph: A collision set contains two groups, Objects A and Objects B, in which you place the objects to detect any collisions between them. When any object in Objects A collides with any object in Objects B, the collision is displayed in the graphical view and logged in the Output window. You can have several collision sets in the station, but each collision set can only contain two groups.

A common use of collision sets is to create one collision set for each robot in the station. For each collision set you then put the robot and its tool in one group and all objects you do not want it to collide with in the other. If a robot has several tools, or holds other objects, you can either add these to the robotâs group as well or create specific collision sets for these setups.
Each collision set can be activated and deactivated separately.

wrapper.title: Collisions and near-misses
wrapper.paragraph: In addition to collisions, the collision detection can also watch for near-misses, which is when an object in Objects A comes within a specified distance from an object in Objects B.

wrapper.title: Recommendations for collision detection
wrapper.paragraph: In general, the following principles are recommended to facilitate collision detection:

listitem.paragraph: Use as small collision sets as possible, split large parts and collect only relevant parts in the collision sets.
Enable coarse detail level while importing geometry.
Limit the use of near-miss.
Enable last collision detection, if the results are acceptable.

wrapper.paragraph: To customize the collision settings, on the File tab, click Options and then select Options:Simulation:Collision.

td.paragraph: Select if collision detection is to be performed during simulation or always. Default value: always.
Select this check box if you want the simulation to stop at a collision or at a near miss. Default value: cleared.
Select this check box if you want the collisions to be logged to the output window. Default value: selected.
Select this check box if you want to log the collisions to a file. Browse for the file to log in by clicking the browse button. Default value: cleared.

Select this check box to enhance the performance by detecting collisions between geometrical bounding boxes instead of geometrical triangles. This might result in falsely reported collisions, since the triangles are the true geometry and the bounding boxes always are larger. All true collisions will, however, be reported. The larger the object, the greater the number of false collisions that are likely to be detected.
Click this button to open the log file specified in the file box in Notepad.
Click this button to delete the log file specified in the file box.
Click this button to browse for the file in which you want to log the collisions.

listitem.paragraph: Click Create Collision Set to create a collision set in the Layout browser.
Expand the collision set and then drag one of the objects to the ObjectsA node to check for collisions.
If you have several objects you want to check for collisions with objects in the ObjectsB node, for example, the tool and the robot, drag all of them to the ObjectsA node.
Drag the objects to the ObjectsB node to check for collisions.
If you have several objects you want to check for collisions with objects in the ObjectsA node, for example, the work piece and the fixture, drag all of them to he ObjectsB node.

wrapper.paragraph: Selecting a collision set or one of its groups (Objects A or Objects B) highlights the corresponding objects in the graphical window and the browser. Use this feature to quickly check what objects have been added to a collision set or to one of its groups.

wrapper.title: Results of creating a collision set
wrapper.paragraph: After you have created a collision set, RobotStudio will check the positions of all objects and detect when any object in ObjectsA collides with any object in ObjectsB. Activation of detection and display of collisions depend on how the collision detection is set up.
If the collision set is active, RobotStudio will check the positions of the objects in the groups, and indicate any collision between them according to the current color settings.

wrapper.title: Collision detection detecting collision
wrapper.paragraph: Collision detection checks whether robots or other moving parts collide with equipment in the station. In complex stations, you can use several collision sets for detecting collisions between several groups of objects.
After collision detection has been set up, it does not need to be started, but automatically detects collisions according to the setup.

wrapper.title: Setting the objects for collision detection
wrapper.paragraph: To set the objects for collision detection, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: Make sure that the objects for collision detection are placed correctly in collision sets.
Make sure that the collision set for the objects is activated, which is indicated by an icon in the Layout browser:

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; dpi=72; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

td.paragraph: Active. Collisions between objects in this set will be detected.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; dpi=72; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

td.paragraph: Not active. Collisions between objects in this set will not be detected.

listitem.paragraph: To activate or deactivate collision sets, continue with the following steps:
Right-click the collision set to change and then click Modify Collision set to bring up a dialog box.
Select or clear the Active check box and then click Apply.

wrapper.title: Setting near-miss detection near-miss detection
wrapper.paragraph: Near-misses occur when objects in collision sets are close to colliding. Each collision set has its own near-miss settings. For setting near-miss detection, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In the Layout browser, right-click the collision set to change and then click Modify Collision set to bring up a dialog box.
In the Near miss box, specify the maximum distance between the objects to be considered a near-miss and then click Apply.

wrapper.title: Setting logging options
wrapper.paragraph: In addition to the graphical display of collisions, you can also log the collisions to the Output window or a separate log file:

listitem.paragraph: On the File menu, click Options, under Simulation, click Collision.
On the Navigation pane to the left, select Simulation: Collision.
On the Collision page to the right, select Log collisions to Output window check box.
The collision log is displayed in the Output window.
On the Collision page to the right, select Log collisions to file check box and enter the name and path to the log file in the box.
A separate file for logging collisions is created below the check box.

wrapper.title: Modifying a collision set
wrapper.paragraph: To modify a collision set, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: Right-click the collision set and then select Modify Collision set from the context menu. The Modify Collision set dialog box opens.
Select or enter the required values in various fields provided in the dialog box.
Click Apply.

wrapper.paragraph: The Modify Collision set dialog box provides the following options:

td.paragraph: Collisions between objects in this set will be detected.
Specifies the maximum distance between the objects to be considered a near miss.
Lets the user select the colliding object (part, body, or surface) that must be highlighted when two objects collide. It also creates a temporary markup at the point of collision or near miss.
Displays the collision in the selected color.
Displays the near miss in the selected color.
Shows markup at collision or near miss.
Detect collisions even if the objects are invisible.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The Collision Avoidance function monitors the geometries of the robot and its work envelope and stops the robot from a possible collision. The static geometry surrounding the robot can also be included in the configuration. This is useful where object positions are dynamically created during runtime by cameras or sensors. The predicted collision can be visualized in the RobotStudio Online Monitor. Collision Avoidance is active during jogging and program execution.

The Collision Prediction supports convex geometries such as points, line segments, and convex polygons. Non-convex objects must be split into smaller parts that can be approximated. The Convex Hull has two parameters for controlling the complexity of the collision model, Max outside tolerance and Max inside tolerance. The Max outside tolerance allows inclusion of a bigger approximated object than the original geometry. The Max inside tolerance allows the approximated object to be smaller than the original geometry.

A premium license of RobotStudio is required to load a geometrical object of type *.SAT. The corresponding CAD converter option is required for other formats. Only polygon models can be loaded in the Basic version.
Collision Avoidance shall not be used for safety of personnel.

wrapper.title: Activating Collision Avoidance
wrapper.paragraph: This feature can be activated from the Controller tab.

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller tab, in the Configuration group, click Collision Avoidance and select Activate Collision Avoidance.
Alternatively, in the Controller browser, right-click any controller and from the context menu, click Collision Avoidance and select Activate Collision Avoidance.

wrapper.title: Configuring collision avoidance

listitem.paragraph: In the Configuration group, select Collision Avoidance > Configure.
The Collision Avoidance window appears.
Under Objects group, click Add, and select Station object, Primitive, or Load geometry... from the drop-down list.
This option allows you to create collision models for predicting collision.

td.paragraph: Add an existing object or modify its properties
Add an object and modify its properties
Add smart gripper fingers (only applicable for YuMi)
Add a CAD geometry and modify its properties

listitem.paragraph: The Collision Object Properties dialog box opens, set and modify the Properties, Convex Hull, and Position of the object.
Under Properties, additional I/O features can be selected and configured.

td.paragraph: Any collision object can be configured with an activation signal that controls whether the object is Active or not. This signal is useful while modelling several tools where only one tool is Active at a time. It can also be useful for modelling objects that may be present in the robot cell, such as a pallet.
The signal must correspond to a digital input.

Any non-moving collision object can be configured with a stop-active signal. This signal determines whether the stopping functionality of the zone is Active or not. If the signal is low, then the robot will not stop when it comes in contact with this zone/collision object.
The signal must correspond to a digital input.
Any non-moving collision object can be configured with a trigger signal. The value of the trigger signal indicates the robots that are in contact with the collision object at a time.
The value of a trigger signal should be interpreted as a bit pattern, where bit k is high if robot k is in contact with the collision object.
Trigger signals can be used to implement safe workspace sharing between multiple robots. The user can specify the timing behavior of the signal in a number of ways.
The signal must map to a group signal in a MultiMove system, otherwise it can be a digital output.

listitem.paragraph: Click OK, to add the object to the Objects list.

wrapper.title: Note
wrapper.paragraph: A maximum of 10 objects can be added.

listitem.paragraph: To easily configure multiple objects, they can be paired.
Under Object Pairs group, click Add, the Collision Pair properties dialog box opens.
Select the objects to be paired for collision avoidance from their respective drop-down lists.
Select the Exclude from collision check checkbox, to exclude the paired object from the collision check.
Select the Override safety distance checkbox, to override the preset safety distance.
Click Ok, to pair the objects and add it to the Object Pairs list.
Click Upload to Controller, to upload the configuration to the robot controller.

wrapper.paragraph: Using the File Transfer feature a collision avoidance file can be transferred from the HOME folder of the virtual controller to the robot controller.

listitem.paragraph: For RobotWare 6, Collision Avoidance is a function included in the option Collision Detection .
Paint robots, IRB 6620LX, and delta robots are not supported.
Collision Avoidance cannot be used in manual mode together with responsive jogging. The system parameter Jog Mode must be changed to Standard .
Only stationary/non-moving objects can be configured with a trigger signal. A trigger signal must correspond to a group signal. Furthermore, each collision object must have its own trigger signal.
There is no support for applications that do corrections to the path, such as conveyor tracking, WeldGuide, Force Control, SoftMove, SoftAct etc.
The Collision Avoidance functionality between 2 robots (or more) can only be achieved when using a MultiMove system.
The smallest dimension for a convex hull is 10 mm. An event log will appear when trying to use too small geometries.

wrapper.title: Setting I/O signals using the I/O Simulator
wrapper.paragraph: The I/O Simulator is used to view and edit I/O signals that are involved in the simulation. Using the I/O simulator window, you can view and manually set existing signals, create lists during program execution, and simulate or manipulate signals.

listitem.paragraph: In Monitor group, click I/O Simulator. This opens the I/O simulator.
If the station contains several virtual controllers, select the appropriate one in the Select Controller list.
In the Filter list and I/O Range list, make selections that display the signals to set. Depending on the filter used, you might also set a filter specification.
To change the value of a digital I/O signal, click it.
To change the value of an analog signal, type the new value in the value box.

wrapper.title: The I/O Simulator window
wrapper.paragraph: The I/O simulator window displays the signals for one virtual controller at a time, in groups of 16 signals. For handling large sets of signals, you can filter which signals to display and also create custom lists with favorite signals for quick access.

td.paragraph: Select System. Select the required virtual controller to view the signals.
Filter type. Select the type of filter to use.
Filter Specification. Select the filter for limiting the signal display. For example, if Board is set as filter type, then select the board to view its signals.
Inputs. Displays all input signals that pass the applied filter.
If more than 16 signals pass, only 16 signals at a time are displayed. Then use the I/O range list to select the signals to view.
Outputs Displays all output signals that pass the applied filter. If more than 16 signals pass, only 16 signals at a time are displayed. Then use the I/O range list to select the signals to view.
Edit Lists. Click this button to create or edit lists of favorite signals.
I/O Range. When more than 16 signals pass the filter, use this list to select the range of signals to display.
Displays all signals on a specific board. To select a board, use the Filter Specification list.
Dispalys a group input or group output signal. To select a group, use the Filter Specification list.
Displays all signals in a favorite list. To select a list, use the Filter Specification list.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; dpi=96; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in
align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; dpi=96; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in
align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; dpi=96; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

td.paragraph: The cross in the upper right corner indicates that the signals are a cross-connection.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; dpi=96; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

td.paragraph: The -1 in the upper right corner indicates that the signal is inverted.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; dpi=96; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

td.paragraph: Value box for groups or analog signals.

wrapper.title: Stopwatch for measuring process time
wrapper.paragraph: The Stopwatch feature is used for measuring the time taken between two trigger points in a simulation, and also for the simulation as a whole. The two trigger points are called the Start Trigger and the End Trigger. When a stopwatch is setup, the timer starts when the Start Trigger occurs, and stops when the End Trigger occurs.
The status bar shows the simulation time during the simulation.

listitem.paragraph: On the Simulation tab, in the Monitor group, click Stopwatch.
The Stopwatch settings dialog appears.
Click Add button, and specify a Name for the stopwatch.
Select a Start Trigger and an End Trigger for the stopwatch.
The following parameters are listed for selection as triggers:
Simulation Start
Simulation Stop
Target Changed
Additionally, specify the mechanical Unit and the target.
I/O Value
Additionally, specify the source mechanical unit from where the signal comes, the type of I/O signal and the value of the signal.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: TCP trace displays the movement of the robot in a simulation, it traces the movement of the TCP. This data provides an overview of certain parameters. A typical example is using TCP trace to monitor TCP speed. The TCP trace can be colored by the speed of the robot to get the qualitative overview of the variation in speed throughout robot motion. This data can be used to find issues in speed calculations and for optimizing the program.

listitem.paragraph: On the Simulation tab, in the Monitor group, click TCP Trace. The TCP trace browser opens.
Select the robot form the Robot drop down option.
Select Enable TCP Trace check box to enable tracing.
Select Color by signal check box and then click .. button. The Select Signal dialog opens.
Open the Mechanical Units node and then select Speed In Current Wobj in the TCP node and click OK.
Select the Use color scale box, and enter the values in the From and To boxes.

wrapper.paragraph: The Use color scale defines how the trace shall be colored. As the signal changes between the values defined in the From and To boxes, the color of the trace also varies according to the color scale.

listitem.paragraph: In the Simulation Control group, click Play to view the color of the trace when the speed signal is used in the simulation.
In the TCP Trace browser, select Enable TCP Trace check box to enable tracing.
Select Color by signal check box and then click .. button. The Select Signal dialog opens.
Open the I/O System node and then select DRV1K1 in the DRV_1 node and click OK.
Select the Use secondary color: box and then select high/low in the when signal is drop-down.

wrapper.paragraph: The color assigned to the trace gets displayed when the signal value meets the specified conditions.

listitem.paragraph: In the Simulation Control group, click Play to view the trace with the change in signal strength.
In the TCP Trace browser, select Show events check box, and then click Select events to open the list of events.
In Select events dialog, select the events that must be monitored. Click OK.
In the Simulation Control group, click Play. The selected events gets displayed along trace as markups during simulation.

wrapper.title: Visualizing TCP stop positions along the path
wrapper.paragraph: TCP stop position indicates the final stopping position of the TCP when a stop category 0 or stop category 1 occurs.

listitem.paragraph: In the TCP Trace browser, select Enable TCP Trace and Show stop position check boxes, and then select stop category 0 or stop category 1 and color.
In the Simulation Control group, click Play, the stop category 0 or stop category 1 positions are displayed along the path.

Here the TCP trace gets marked in the primary color and the TCP stop positions in the selected color. At regular intervals along the path, programmed TCP positions are connected to the corresponding TCP stop positions with straight lines.

wrapper.paragraph: The measurement and calculation of overall stopping performance for a robot must be tested with its correct load, speed, and tools, in its actual environment, before the robot is taken into production, see ISO 13855:2010.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Smart Components are RobotStudio objects with built-in properties and logic for simulating components that are not part of the virtual controller. RobotStudio, by default, offers a set of Base Smart Components for basic motion, signal logic, arithmetic, parametric modeling, sensors and so on.

Base Smart Components can be used to build user defined Smart Components with more complex properties. Some examples are gripper motion, objects moving on conveyors, logic and so on. Smart Components can be saved as library files for reuse.

wrapper.title: Purpose of Smart Components
wrapper.paragraph: Smart Components provide a graphical programming interface for creating complex components that can be part of stations and simulations. RobotStudio provides Base Smart Components that are required for all possible simulation scenarios. If the property of a certain component is complex and it cannot be simulated by using the Base Smart Components, then code behind can be used. With code behind, it is possible for a developer to program a .NET assembly within the component to customize the Smart Component.
Refer http://developercenter.robotstudio.com/robotstudio for more details.

wrapper.title: Accessing the Base Smart Components
wrapper.paragraph: The Smart Component Editor allows you to create, edit, and aggregate Smart Components using a graphical user interface. On the Modelling tab, in the Create group, click Smart Component or right click on the smart component present on the context menu and select Edit Component. The Smart Component Editor window appears.

It is possible to protect a Smart Component from being edited. To create a protected smart component, right-click the smart component, and then click Protected. You can also optionally specify a password that will be required to unlock the component for edits.
Information about Base Smart Components are listed against the selection in the Smart Component editor.

wrapper.title: Building blocks of a Smart Component
wrapper.paragraph: Properties and Bindings: Properties represent the collection of various parameters that define a Smart Component. The property of a Smart Component is significant while designing complex Smart Components from Base Smart Components. Consider the example of the Smart Component, Line Sensor, which detects if any object intersects a line between two points.

Properties of Line Sensor that are considered in the following example are Start point, End Point and Sensed Part. Here, the Start and end points set the distance where the Line Sensor is in Active state. The Sensed Part decides which object the Line Sensor detects, for example, a box that moves on a belt conveyor.

When the Line Sensor senses the box , the property Sensed Part detects the box. If you want the box to be picked by another Smart Component, for example, a Gripper, the property of the Line Sensor must be connected to the Gripper such that it is ready to grip the box. This is achieved using property bindings. Property bindings connect the value of one property to the value of another property.

Signals: Signals are the property of the Smart Component that has a value, type and direction (input/output). These signals are analogous to the I/O signals on a robot controller. During simulation, the signal values control the responses of the Smart Component. Connections create a tunnel for information to move from the signal of one component to the a signal of another component.

It is possible to rename Smart Component signals and properties in the Station Logic Design tab. To rename a signal, right-click the signal and then click Properties, the Edit dialog opens, type-in the changes and click OK.
Asset: These are other files embedded into a Smart Component for perfecting its execution, such as external data files or 3D models.
State: State refers to the parameter values of various components in the Smart Component at a given time. These parameters are, I/O Signal value, Property value and so on.

wrapper.title: Grouping signals and properties of Smart Components
wrapper.paragraph: Properties and signals of Smart Components can be organized and combined into groups for a filtered view. This feature is useful when working with complex Smart Components consisting of many properties and signals where similar properties or signals can be categorized into groups.
Use the following procedure to create a group and add properties to the group.

listitem.paragraph: In the Smart Component Editor, click the Properties and Bindings tab and then click Add Dynamic Property.
In the Add Dynamic Property window, enter a valid name in the Group box and then click OK. A new group gets created in the Smart Component Properties browser.
To add an existing property to a group, with the property selected, click Edit and then in the edit dialog, select the Group and click OK.

wrapper.paragraph: In the Smart Component Editor, click the Signals and Connectors tab and then follow the same procedure to create a group for signals and to add signals to groups.

wrapper.title: Importing and Exporting I/O Connections and Property Bindings
wrapper.paragraph: Station Logic I/O Connections and Property Bindings of a Smart Component can be imported to or exported from an Excel document.
To export I/O Connections or Property Bindings:

listitem.paragraph: In Station Logic, click the Design tab, then right-click and access the context menu.
In the context menu, click Export and then click Export I/O Connections... or Export Property Bindings....

wrapper.paragraph: Similarly, to import I/O Connections or Property Bindings, in the context menu, click Import and then click Import I/O Connections... or Import Property Bindings...
Alternatively, Export and Import buttons are available in both Properties and Bindings and Signals and Connections tabs.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The base components represent a complete set of basic building block components. They can be used to build user defined Smart Components with more complex behavior.
The signal Output is set by the logical operation specified in Operator of the two signals InputAand InputB, with the delay specified in Delay.

td.paragraph: The following lists the various operators:
Time to delay the output signal.
The result of the logic operation.

wrapper.paragraph: Evaluates a logic expression.

td.paragraph: Expression to evaluate. Supports logic operators AND, OR, NOT, XOR. Input signals are automatically added for other identifiers.
Contains the result of the evaluation.

wrapper.paragraph: Output is set according to: Output = (Input A * NOT Selector) + (Input B * Selector)

td.paragraph: Set to 0 to select first input, 1 to select second input.
Specifies the result of the operation.

wrapper.paragraph: The LogicSplit takes Input and sets OutputHigh to the same as Input, and OutputLow as the inverse of Input.
PulseHigh sends a pulse when Input is set to high, and PulseLow sends a pulse when Input is set to low.

td.paragraph: Sends pulse when input is set to high.
Sends pulse when input is set to low.

wrapper.paragraph: TheLogicSRLatch has one stable state.

listitem.paragraph: When Set=1, Output=1 and InvOutput=0
When Reset=1, Output=0 and InvOutput=1

wrapper.paragraph: Converts between property values and signal values.

td.paragraph: Converts from DigitalInput and to DigitalOutput.

wrapper.paragraph: Converts between Vector3 and X, Y,and Z values.

The Expression consists of numeric literals (including PI), parentheses, mathematical operators +,-,*,/,^ (power) and mathematical functions sin, cos, sqrt, atan, abs. Any other strings are interpreted as variables, which are added as additional properties. The result is displayed in Result.
The Comparer compares First value with Second value, using Operator. Output is set to 1 if the condition is met.

td.paragraph: The following lists the various operators:
Goes high (1) if the comparison evaluates to true.

wrapper.paragraph: Count is increased when the input signal Increase is set, and decreased when the input signal Decrease is set. Count is reset when the input signal Reset is set.

td.paragraph: Set to high (1) to increase the count.
Set to high (1) to decrease the count.
Set to high (1) to reset the count to zero.

wrapper.paragraph: Pulses Output signal Count number of times.

td.paragraph: Number of times to pulse Output.
Set to high (1) to pulse Output Count times.

wrapper.paragraph: The Timer pulses the Output signal based on the given interval.
If Repeat is unchecked, one pulse will be triggered after the time specified in Interval. Otherwise, the pulse will be repeated at the interval given by Interval.

td.paragraph: Specifies the time to pass before the first pulse.
Specifies the simulation time between the pulses.
Specifies if the signal should be pulsed repeatedly or only once.
Set to high (1) to activate the timer.
Goes high (1) and then low (0) at the specified interval.
Set to high (1) to reset the current time.

wrapper.paragraph: The StopWatch measures time during simulation (TotalTime). A new lap can be started by triggering the Lap input signal. LapTime shows the current lap time. The time is only measured when Active is set to 1. The times are reset when the input signal Reset is set.

td.paragraph: If true, TotalTime and LapTime will be set to 0 when the simulation starts.
Resets the stopwatch when the simulation is started.
Set to high (1) to activate the stopwatch.
Set to high (1) to reset the stopwatch.
Set to high (1) to start a new lap

wrapper.paragraph: The Timer pulses digital signals at specified times during simulation.

td.paragraph: Time when the corresponding output is pulsed.
Set to high (1) to activate the timer.
Set to high (1) to reset the current time.
Goes high (1) and then low (0) at the specified time.

wrapper.paragraph: Formats a string from input properties.

td.paragraph: Format string. Supports variables like {id:type}, where type can be d (double), i (int), s (string), o (object).

wrapper.paragraph: The ParametricBox generates a box with dimensions specified by length, width, and height.

td.paragraph: Specifies the length of the box in the X-axis direction.
Specifies the length of the box in the Y-axis direction.
Specifies the length of the box in the Z-axis direction
False to remove the geometry data from the generated part. This can make other components such as Source execute faster.
Set to high (1) to update the generated part.

wrapper.paragraph: The ParametricCylinder generates a cylinder with the dimensions given by Radius and Height.

td.paragraph: Specifies the radius of the cylinder.
Specifies the height of the cylinder.
False to remove the geometry data from the generated part. This can make other components such as Source execute faster.
Set to high (1) to update the generated part.

wrapper.paragraph: The ParametricLine generates a line with a given end point or a given length. If either of them is changed, the other one will be updated accordingly.

td.paragraph: Specifies the end point for the line.
Specifies the length of the line.
False to remove the geometry data from the generated part. This can make other components such as Source execute faster.
Set to high (1) to update the generated part.

wrapper.paragraph: The ParametricCircle generates a circle with a given radius.

td.paragraph: Specifies the radius of the circle.
False to remove the geometry data from the generated part. This can make other components such as Source execute faster
Set to high (1) to update the generated part.

wrapper.paragraph: The LinearExtrusion extrudes SourceFace or SourceWire along the vector given by Projection.

td.paragraph: Specifies the vector to extrude along.
False to remove the geometry data from the generated part. This can make other components such as Source execute faster.
Set to high (1) to update the generated part.

wrapper.paragraph: The LinearRepeater creates a number of copies of Source, with the spacing and direction given by Offset.

td.paragraph: Specifies the distance between the copies.
Specifies the number of copies to create.

wrapper.paragraph: The MatrixRepeater creates a specified number of copies in three dimensions, with the specified spacing of the object in Source.

td.paragraph: Specifies the number of copies in the X-axis direction.
Specifies the number of copies in the Y-axis direction.
Specifies the number of copies in the Z-axis direction.
Specifies the offset between the copies in the X-axis direction.
Specifies the offset between the copies in the Y-axis direction.
Specifies the offset between the copies in the Z-axis direction.

wrapper.paragraph: The CircularRepeater creates a number of given copies of Source around the center of the SmartComponent with a given DeltaAngle.

td.paragraph: Specifies the number of copies to create.
Specifies the radius of the circle.
Specifies the angle between the copies.

wrapper.paragraph: The CollisionSensor detects collisions and near miss events between the First object and the Second object. If one of the objects is not specified, the other will be checked against the entire station. When the Active signal is high and a collision or a near miss event occurs and the component is active, the SensorOut signal is set and the parts that participate in the collision or near miss event are reported in the first colliding part and second colliding partof the Property editor.

td.paragraph: The first object to check for collisions.
The second object to check for collisions.
The part of First object that has a collision.
The part of Second object that has a collision.
Set to high (1) to activate the sensor.
Goes high (1) when a collision or near miss occurs.

wrapper.paragraph: The LineSensor defines a line by the Start, End, and Radius. When an Active signal is high, the sensor detects objects that intersect the line. Intersecting objects are displayed in the ClosestPart property and the point on the intersecting part that is closest to the line sensors start point is displayed in the ClosestPoint property. When intersection occurs the SensorOut output signal is set.

td.paragraph: Specifies the part that intersects the line sensor.
If several parts intersect, then the part that is closest to the Start point is listed.
Specifies the point on the intersecting part, closest to the Start point.
Specifies the distance between the sensor start and end points.

The Length property can be used to adjust the length of the sensor after the direction has been specified with the start and end points. When the Length property is changed, the end point is updated accordingly along the direction of the sensor automatically.
When a tag is specified, the sensor detects only objects with the same tag.
Set to 1 to activate the sensor.
Goes high (1) when an object intersects the line.

wrapper.paragraph: The PlaneSensor defines a plane by Origin, Axis1, and Axis2. When the Active input signal is set the sensor detects objects that intersect this plane. Intersecting objects are displayed in the SensedPart property and when intersection occurs the SensorOut output signal is set.

td.paragraph: Specifies the origin of the plane.
Specifies the first axis of the plane.
Specifies the second axis of the plane.
Specifies the part that intersects the PlaneSensor.
If several parts intersect, then the one listed first in the Layout browser is selected.
When a tag is specified, the sensor detects only objects with the same tag.
Set to high (1) to activate the sensor.
Goes high (1) when an object intersects the plane.

wrapper.paragraph: The VolumeSensor detects objects that are inside or partly inside a box-shaped volume. The volume is defined by a Corner Point, the Length, Height, and Width of the sides and the orientation angles.

td.paragraph: Specifies the local origin of the box.
Specifies the orientation (Euler ZYX) relative to Reference.
Specifies the length of the box.
Specifies the width of the box.
Specifies the height of the box.
The percentage of the volume to react on. Set to 0 to react on all objects.
Allow an object to be sensed if only a part of it is inside the volume sensor.
The last object that either entered or left the volume.
The objects sensed in the volume.
When a tag is specified, the sensor detects only objects with the same tag.
Set to high (1) to activate the sensor.
Goes high (1) when an object is detected.

wrapper.paragraph: The PositionSensor monitors the position and orientation of an object.
The position and orientation of an object is updated only during the simulation.

td.paragraph: Specifies the reference coordinate system (Parent or Global).
Specifies the reference object, if Reference is set to Object.
Specifies the position of the object relative to Reference.
Specifies the orientation (Euler ZYX) relative to Reference.
Goes high (1) when Position or Orientation have changed.

wrapper.paragraph: The ClosestObject defines a Reference object or a Reference point. When the Execute signal is set, the component finds the ClosestObject, ClosestPart, and the Distance to the reference object, or to the reference point if the reference object is undefined. If RootObject is defined, the search is limited to that object and its descendants. When finished and the corresponding properties are updated the Executed signal is set.

td.paragraph: Specifies the object to get the closest object to.
Specifies the point to get the closest object to.
Specifies the object whose children to search.
Specifies the object closest to Reference object or Reference point.
Specifies the part closest to Reference object or Reference point.
Specifies the distance between the Reference object and the Closest object.
Set to high (1) to set find the closest object.
Goes high (1) when the operation is completed.

wrapper.paragraph: Monitors mechanism joint values during simulation

td.paragraph: Set to high (1) to update the joint values.

wrapper.paragraph: The GetParent returns the parent object of the input object. The executed signal is triggered if a parent is found.

td.paragraph: Specifies the object to whose parent is to be found.
Specifies the parent of the child

wrapper.paragraph: The Child list for Properties:GetParent does not show every part or object in the station. However, if you do not find the required part or object in the list, then add it from the browser or graphic window by clicking it.

The Attacher will attach Child to Parent when the Execute signal is set. If the Parent is a mechanism, the Flange to attach to must also be specified. When the input Execute is set, the child object is attached to the parent object. If Mount is checked, the child will also be mounted on the parent, with the Offset and Orientation specified. The output Executed will be set when finished.

td.paragraph: Specifies the object to attach to.
Specifies the Index of mechanism flange to attach to.
If true, the object to attach mounts on the attachment parent.
Specifies the position relative to the attachment parent when using Mount.
Specifies the orientation relative to the attachment parent when using Mount.
Set to high (1) to create the attachment.
Goes high (1) when the operation is complete.

wrapper.paragraph: The Detacher will detach the Child from the object it is attached to when the Execute signal is set. If Keep position is checked, the position will be kept. Otherwise the child is positioned relative to its parent. When finished, the Executed signal will be set.

td.paragraph: If false, the attached object is returned to its original position.
Set to high (1) to remove the attachment.
Goes high (1) when the operation is complete.

wrapper.paragraph: The Source property of the source component indicates the object that should be cloned when the Execute input signal is received. The parent of the cloned objects is specified by the Parent property and a reference to the cloned object is specified by the Copy property. The output signal Executed signifies that the clone is complete.

td.paragraph: Specifies the parent to the copy.
If not specified, the copy gets the same parent as the source.
Specifies the position of the copy relative its parent.
Specifies the orientation of the copy relative its parent.

Marks the copy as transient if created during simulation. Such copies are not added to the undo queue and are automatically deleted when the simulation is stopped. This is used to avoid increased memory consumption during simulation.
Specifies the physics behavior of the copy.
Set to high (1) to create the copy.
Goes high (1) when the operation is complete.

wrapper.paragraph: The Sink deletes the object referenced by the Object property. Deletion happens when the Execute input signal is received. The Executed output signal is set when the deletion is finished.

td.paragraph: Set to high (1) to remove the object.
Goes high (1) when the operation is complete.

wrapper.paragraph: When the Execute signal is set, the object referenced in Object appears. When finished, Executed signal will be set.

td.paragraph: Set to True to show the object.

wrapper.paragraph: When the Execute signal is set, the object referenced in Object will be hidden. When finished, Executed signal will be set.

td.paragraph: Set to True to hide the object.

wrapper.paragraph: Sets the parent of a graphic component.

td.paragraph: The graphic component whose parent is to be set.
To keep the position and orientation of the child object.
Set to high (1) to move the child object to the new parent.

wrapper.paragraph: The LinearMover moves the object referenced in the Object property with a speed given by the Speed property in the direction given by the Direction property. The motion starts when the Execute input signal is set and stops when Execute is reset.

td.paragraph: Specifies the direction to move the object.
Specifies the coordinate system in which values are specified. It can be Global, Local, or Object.
Specifies the reference object, if Reference is set to Object.
Set to high (1) to start moving the object.

wrapper.paragraph: The LinearMover moves an object a specified distance.

td.paragraph: Specifies the direction to move the object.
Specifies the distance to move the object.
Specifies the time for the movement.
Specifies the coordinate system in which values are specified. It can be Global, Local, or Object.
Set to high (1) to start the movement.
Goes high (1) when the movement is completed.

wrapper.paragraph: The Rotator rotates the object referenced in the Object property with an angular speed given by the Speed property. The axis of rotation is given by CenterPoint and Axis. The motion starts when the Execute input signal is set and stops when the Execute is reset.

td.paragraph: Specifies the point to rotate around.
Specifies the axis of the rotation.
Specifies the speed of the rotation.
Specifies the coordinate system in which values are specified. It can be Global, Local, or Object.
Specifies the object which are relative to CenterPoint and Axis, if Reference is set to Object.
Set to high (1) to start rotating the object.

wrapper.paragraph: The Rotator rotates an object a specified angle around an axis.

td.paragraph: Specifies the point to rotate around.
Specifies the axis of the rotation.
Specifies the time for the movement.
Specifies the coordinate system in which values are specified. It can be Global, Local, or Object.
Set to high (1) to start the movement.
Goes high (1) when the movement is completed.

wrapper.paragraph: The PoseMover has a Mechanism, a Pose, and Duration as properties. When the Execute input signal is set the mechanism joint values are moved to the given pose. When the pose is reached the Executed output signal is set.

td.paragraph: Specifies the mechanism to move to a pose.
Specifies the Index of the pose to move to.
Specifies the time for the mechanism to move to the pose.
Set to True, to start or resume moving the mechanism.
Pulses high when the mechanism has reached the pose.

wrapper.paragraph: The JointMover has a Mechanism, a set of Joint Values and a Duration as properties. When the Execute input signal is set the mechanism joint values are moved to the given pose. When the pose is reached the Executed output signal is set. The GetCurrent signal retrieves the current joint values of the mechanism.

td.paragraph: Specifies the mechanism to move to a pose.
Specifies if J1-Jx are relative to the start values, rather than absolute joint values.
Specifies the time for the mechanism to move to the pose.
Set to True to start moving the mechanism.
Pulses high when the mechanism has reached the pose.

wrapper.paragraph: The Positioner takes an Object, Position, and Orientation as properties. When the Execute signal is set the object is repositioned in the given position relative to the Reference. When finished the Executed output is set.

td.paragraph: Specifies the new position of the object.
Specifies the new orientation of the object.
Specifies the coordinate system in which values are specified. It can be Global, Local, or Object.
Specifies the object which are relative to Position and Orientation, if Reference is set to Object.
Set to high (1) to set the position.
Goes high (1) when the operation is completed.

wrapper.paragraph: Moves an object along a geometric curve (using a constant offset).

td.paragraph: Specifies the part that contains wire(s) to move along.
Set to true to keep the orientation of the object.
Where along the curve to start the movement.
Set to high (1) to start the movement.
Set to high (1) to cancel the movement.
Goes high (1) when the movement is paused.
Goes high (1) when the movement is completed.

wrapper.paragraph: Sets or gets the value of a RAPID variable.

td.paragraph: RAPID datatype of the variable to get or set (bool, num, dnum, string, pos, orient, or pose)
The virtual controller that contains the variable.
The RAPID task that contains the variable.
The RAPID module in which the variable is defined.
The name of the RAPID variable
The variable value and the type depends on DataType.
Set to high (1) to get the value.
Set to high (1) to set the value.
Is pulsed when the value is updated.

wrapper.paragraph: Controls the physics related properties of parts or component groups.

td.paragraph: Determines the behavior of the object in the physics simulation.
Set to high (1) to enable physics behavior.
Set to high (1) to enable surface velocity.

wrapper.paragraph: Controls properties of a physics joint.

td.paragraph: Sets the speed of a motorized joint.
Enables or disables the joint motor.

wrapper.title: OpcUaClient
wrapper.paragraph: An OPC UA client.

td.paragraph: The IP address and the port number to the OPC UA server.
Enables encrypted connection and requires a trusted server certificate.
Enables automatic connection when loading the station and after a connection failure.
When enabled the simulation will wait for the OPC UA communication to complete in each time step.
Enables choosing authentication type for connecting to the OPC UA server.

wrapper.paragraph: Following signals are available as commands in the context menu.

td.paragraph: Connect to the OPC UA server.
Disconnect from the OPC UA server.
Connect to the OPC UA server with a different user.
Configure the mapping between OPC UA server nodes and RobotStudio signals.
Import the mapping between OPC UA server nodes and RobotStudio signals.
Export the mapping between OPC UA server nodes and RobotStudio signals.

wrapper.title: SIMITConnection
wrapper.paragraph: Siemens SIMIT connection via Shared Memory.
Following signals are available as commands in the context menu.

wrapper.title: VrHandController
wrapper.paragraph: A component that moves with a hand controller in VR

td.paragraph: Selects if the tip or the base of the hand controller is tracked.
Goes to high (1) when the primary trigger is pressed.

wrapper.title: VrSession
wrapper.paragraph: Adds custom buttons to a VR menu pane, and signals when the user exits or enters VR

td.paragraph: Pulsed when the user starts VR.
Pulsed when the user exits VR.

wrapper.title: VrTeleporter
wrapper.paragraph: Teleports the VR user to the location of the component

td.paragraph: Set to high (1) to execute the teleport.

wrapper.paragraph: The Queue represents a FIFO (first in, first out) queue. The object in Back is added to the queue when the signal Enqueue is set. The front object of the queue is shown in Front. The object in Front is removed from the queue when the signal Dequeue is set. If there are more objects in the queue, the next object is shown in Front. All objects in the queue are removed from the queue when the signal Clear is set.
If a transformer component (such as LinearMover) has a queue component as its Object, it will transform the contents of the queue, rather than the queue itself.

td.paragraph: Specifies the first object in queue.
Specifies the number of objects in the queue.
Adds the object in Back to the end of the queue.
Removes the object in Front from the queue.
Removes all objects from the queue.
Removes the object in Front from the queue and from the station.
Clears the queue and removes all objects from the station

wrapper.paragraph: Sets a digital signal as a result of an object comparison. Determines if ObjectA is the same as ObjectB.

td.paragraph: Specifies the first object to compare.
Specifies the second object to compare.
Goes high (1) if the objects are equal.

wrapper.paragraph: Switches between two parts, either by clicking on the visible part in the graphics or by setting and resetting the input signal.

td.paragraph: Displayed when the signal is high.
Displayed when the signal is low.
Output signal high (1) when PartHigh is displayed, and low (0) when PartLow is displayed.

wrapper.paragraph: The Highlighter temporarily sets the color of the Object to the RGB-values specified in Color. The color is blended with the original color of the objects as defined by Opacity When the signal Active is reset, Object gets its original colors.

td.paragraph: Specifies the RGB-values of the highlight color.
Specifies the amount to blend with the object's original color (0-255).
Set to high (1) to change the color, low (0) to restore the original color.

wrapper.paragraph: Moves to the selected viewpoint in the given time, when the input signal Execute is set. The output signal Executed is set when the operation is completed.

td.paragraph: Specifies the viewpoint to move to.
Specifies the time to complete the operation.
Set to high (1) to start the operation.
Goes high (1) when the operation is completed.

wrapper.paragraph: Prints a message in the output window.

td.paragraph: Supports variables like {id:type}, where type can be d (double), i (int), s (string), o (object)
Set to high (1) to print the message.

wrapper.paragraph: Plays the sound specified by Sound Asset when the input signal Execute is set. The asset must be a .wav file

td.paragraph: Specifies the sound file that should be played. Must be a .wav file.
Set to true to loop the sound.
Set to high (1) to play the sound.
Goes high (1) when the sound is played.
Set to high (1) to stop playing.

wrapper.paragraph: Random generates a random number between Min and Max in Value when Execute is triggered.

td.paragraph: Specifies a random number between Min and Max.
Set to high (1) to generate a new random number.
Goes high (1) when the operation is completed.

wrapper.paragraph: Stop a running simulation when the input signal Execute is set.

td.paragraph: Set to high (1) to stop the simulation.

wrapper.paragraph: Enables or disables TCP trace for a robot.

td.paragraph: Set to high (1) to enable TCP trace.
Set to high (1) to clear the TCP trace.

wrapper.paragraph: Pulses signals when the simulation starts and stops.
Controls a light source.

td.paragraph: Sets the color of the light.
