Note also that this procedure will not automatically include RAPID programs and system parameters to your new system. If needed, they can be loaded to the new system by restoring the Backup once the new system is installed and started.

listitem.paragraph: Select OK to continue.
Continue with creating an installation package.

wrapper.title: Creating a new installation package
wrapper.paragraph: The installation package is a software package that consists of predefined directory structure and number of files, used for purpose of re-deploying RobotWare System on a robot controller. The installation package is created in RobotStudio and is deployed on the controller using RobotWare Installation Utilities on the FlexPendant.

RobotWare Installation Utilities is a small package of installation related utilities that is always present on each robot controller and cannot be removed. It is used to deploy and re-deploy RobotWare system which is the operating system of the robot controller. When in RobotWare Installation Utilities mode, the robot cannot be moved using the FlexPendant and robot programs cannot be written or executed.
The following prerequisites must be met before you can start creating an installation package:

listitem.paragraph: Latest version of RobotStudio must be installed.

License files for products to be installed must be available. Licenses are included in the RobotWare system at purchase, but can also be retrieved from a backup of the RobotWare system currently deployed on the controller, or exported from the controller via RobotWare Installation Utilities.

wrapper.paragraph: Virtual licenses can also be used.

listitem.paragraph: Product versions to be installed must be available in RobotStudio or in a custom location.

These versions can be made available by selecting a RobotWare distribution package (.rspak file) from RobotStudio (tap Install Package in the Add-Ins tab). All products that are installed this way, have matched versions and correct dependencies to each other.
A virtual controller must be created.
Start RobotStudio.
Select Add Controller > Connect to Controller in the Controller ribbon.
In the Connect to Controller window, select the controller and tap OK.
Request write access.
Launch the Modify Installation dialog from the Controller ribbon.
Select the tab Software.
Select Create Package to create an installation package based on the virtual controller configuration.

wrapper.paragraph: If the virtual system has been built using virtual licenses, these will not be included in the installation package.

If virtual licenses are used, the selected feature configuration will be matched against the real licenses present in the controller and the installation will stop if some licenses are missing. This situation can be avoided if real licenses from the controller are exported and imported into the virtual system when it is built.

listitem.paragraph: In the Create Installation Package dialog, define the following:
Enter a name for the installation package.
Browse and select the output folder (for example, a USB-stick) for the installation package.
Select OK.
The window Installation Package created is displayed. The installation package for the selected system has been created. Select OK.
Continue with installing the package on the controller.

wrapper.title: Starting Installation Manager
wrapper.paragraph: On the Controller tab, in the Configuration group click Modify Installation to start the Installation Manager application.
This window provides two options. Select Network to create systems for robot controllers and Virtual to create systems for virtual controllers.

wrapper.title: Setting application preferences
wrapper.paragraph: Before creating a system using Installation Manager, it is recommended to set the path to the desired location where products, licenses, and backups are located and where virtual systems will be created.

listitem.paragraph: On the Controller tab, in the Configuration group click Modify Installation.
In the Installation Manager window, click Preferences. The Preferences window opens.
Browse and select folders for Product path(s), License path(s), Virtual systems path(s), and Backup path(s) in respective lists.
The User name and Password boxes are populated with the default credentials provided to you with your RobotStudio license. These credentials are applicable only for a robot controller.
In the Default System Name box, enter the default system name. When you create a new system, this name will be assigned by default.
Click OK to set the preferences.

wrapper.paragraph: Advanced users can select the location to install virtual controllers. Select the Virtual products installation path(s) check box and then click Browse to select the folder. You can see the selected path in the drop-down list box. Clear the check box to enable the default path.

wrapper.title: Settings file
wrapper.paragraph: Settings file contains the selected options. When Installation Manager connects to the robot controller, it reads options from the Settings file. Any change in the options are mapped in the file.
Use the Settings buttons to perform the following tasks with the settings file.

td.paragraph: Click this button to export the current settings of the robot controller.
Click this button to import settings to the robot controller. The current settings of the system will be cleared before performing this operation.
Click this button to add settings to the current setup of the robot controller.
Click this button to revert to the current settings of the robot controller.

wrapper.title: Creating a new system for a robot controller

listitem.paragraph: In the Installation Manager window, click Controllers, and then click the Network tab.
The Network tab shows the name and IP address of all the available controllers on the LAN network and/or any controller attached through the service port.
Select your controller in the controller list and click Open. Installation Manager fetches information from the controller.
Click New. The Create New pane appears.
In the Create New pane, in the Name box, enter the name of the new system.
Click Next. The Products tab gets selected.
Click Add, the Select Product window opens. Select the product manifest file and click OK.
If you want to add more products such as Add-ins, click Add again and select the product. To find a product that is not in the list, click Browse and then select the file from the particular folder.

wrapper.paragraph: The product install order shows the order in which products and Add-ins are installed on the controller. Installing products in the required sequence is important when products are dependent on each other. The product order is assigned to products automatically based on the sequence in which the products must be installed on the controller. This is independent of the order in which products are added to the system.

listitem.paragraph: Click Next. The Licenses tab gets selected.
Click Add, the Select License window opens. Select the license file and click OK.
Repeat the step to add multiple license files to your system.
Click Next, the Options tab gets selected. This pane shows the System Options, Drive Modules and Applications. Here you are able to customize your options.
Click Next, the Confirmation tab gets selected and shows an overview of the system options.
Click Apply, the system gets created on the controller.

wrapper.paragraph: Once the installation completes, a Restart Controller dialog appears, click Yes to restart the controller. Click No to manually restart controller later, the controller stores the new system or the changed system and these changes will take effect during the next restart.
Changing the RobotWare version needs BootServer update. Controller must be restarted for BootServer update. Hence, the controller will be restarted automatically when you change the RobotWare.

wrapper.title: Creating a new system for a virtual controller

listitem.paragraph: In the Installation Manager window, click Controllers, and then click the Virtual tab.
Click New. The Create New pane opens.
In the Create New pane, in the Name box, enter the name of the new system.
Click Next. The Products tab gets selected.
Click Add, the Select Product window opens. Select the product manifest file and click OK.
If you want to add more products such as Add-ins, click Add again and select the product. To find a product that is not in the list, click Browse and then select the file from the particular folder.

wrapper.paragraph: The product install order shows the order in which products and add-ins are installed on the controller. Installing products in the required sequence is important when products are dependent on each other. The product order is assigned to products automatically based on the sequence in which the products must be installed on the controller. This is independent of the order in which products are added to the system.

listitem.paragraph: Click Next. The Licenses tab gets selected.
Click Add, the Select License window opens. Select the license file and click OK.
Repeat the same step to add multiple license files to your system.
Click Next, the Options tab gets selected. This pane shows the System Options, Drive Modules and Applications. Here you are able to customize your options.
Click Next, the Confirmation tab gets selected and shows an overview of the system options.
Click Apply, the system gets created.

wrapper.title: Modifying a system for a robot controller

listitem.paragraph: In the Installation Manager window, select Controllers and then select the Network tab.
Select your controller in the controller list and click Open. Installation Manager fetches information from the controller.
Select the particular system that you want to modify.
The Overview pane displays the system options of the selected system.

wrapper.paragraph: To be able to modify a system it must first be activated. Select the system you want to modify and press the activate button.

listitem.paragraph: Click Next. The Products tab gets selected. All products and add-ins that were part of the selected system will be displayed here.
To upgrade/downgrade a product select the product and click Replace.
To remove a product select the product and click Remove.

wrapper.paragraph: It is not possible to remove the RobotWare product.

listitem.paragraph: Click Next. The Licence tab gets selected. The license details of the selected system will be displayed here. Here you are able to add/remove licenses.
Click Next. The Options tab gets selected. Here you are able to customize your options.
Click Next, the Confirmation tab gets selected and shows an overview of the system options.
Click Apply for the changes to take place.

wrapper.paragraph: Once the installation completes, a Restart Controller dialog appears, click Yes to restart the controller. Click No to manually restart controller later, the controller stores the new system or changed system and these changes will take effect during the next restart.
Any change in the RobotWare version needs a BootServer update, which requires a controller restart. The controller will be restarted automatically.

wrapper.title: Modifying a system for virtual controller

listitem.paragraph: In the Installation Manager window, select Controllers and then select the Virtual. Here you are able to view the list of all virtual systems.
Select the particular system that you want to modify.
The Overview pane will display the system options of the selected system.
Click Next. The Products tab gets selected. All products and add-ins that were part of the selected system will be displayed here.
To upgrade/downgrade a product select the product and click Replace.
To remove a product select the product and click Remove.

wrapper.paragraph: It is not possible to remove the RobotWare product.

listitem.paragraph: Click Next. The Licence tab opens. The license details of the selected system will be displayed here. Here you are able to add/remove licenses.
Click Next. The Options tab opens. This pane shows the System Options, Drive Modules and Applications. Here you are able to customize your options.
Click Next, the Confirmation tab gets selected and shows an overview of the system options.
Click Apply for the changes to take place.

wrapper.title: Deleting a system from a robot controller

listitem.paragraph: In the Installation Manager window, select Controllers and then select the Network tab.
Select your controller in the controller list and click Open. Installation Manager fetches information from the controller.
Select the system you want to delete and then click Remove.
The selected system gets deleted.

wrapper.paragraph: The active system cannot be deleted. First activate a different system, or deactivate the system by using the restart mode Start Boot Application.

wrapper.title: Deleting a system from virtual controller

listitem.paragraph: In the Installation Manager window, select Controllers and then select the Virtual or Network tab. Here you are able to view the list of all virtual systems.
Select the system you want to delete and then click Remove.
The selected system gets deleted.

wrapper.paragraph: When you create a system for virtual controller, corresponding products are installed in the user APPDATA folder, and many virtual controller systems point to these products. Hence, products are not deleted while deleting a system from virtual controller.

wrapper.title: Copying a system from a virtual controller to a robot controller
wrapper.paragraph: To be able to copy a virtual controller to a robot controller, the virtual controller must have been created with real license files.

listitem.paragraph: In the Installation Manager window, select Controllers and then select the Network tab.
Select your controller in the controller list and click Modify. Installation Manager fetches information from the controller.
Click New. The Create New pane opens.
Enter the name of the virtual controller in the Name box, and then click the virtual system option under Create new from.
Click Select, the Select Virtual System pane opens, select the particular system and then click OK.
Click Next. The Products tab gets selected. All products and add-ins that were part of the selected virtual controller will be displayed here.
Click Next. The Licenses tab gets selected. The license details of the selected virtual controller will be displayed here.
Click Next. The Options tab gets selected. Here you are able to select/deselect options to customize them.
Click Next, the Confirmation tab gets selected and shows an overview of the system options.
Click Apply, the system gets created.

wrapper.paragraph: Once the installation completes, a Restart Controller dialog appears, click Yes to restart the controller. Click No to manually restart controller later, the controller stores the new or changed virtual controller and these changes will take effect during the next restart.

listitem.paragraph: In the Installation Manager window, select Controllers and then select the Virtual tab. Here you are able to view the list of all virtual systems.
Click New, the Create New pane opens.
Enter the name of the virtual system in the Name box, and then click the virtual system option under Create.
Click Select, the Select Virtual System pane opens, select the particular system and then click OK.
Click Next. The Products tab gets selected. All products and add-ins that were part of the selected system will be displayed here.
Click Next. The Licence tab gets selected. The license details of the selected system will be displayed here.
Click Next. The Options tab gets selected. Here you are able to select/deselect options to customize them.
Click Next, the Confirmation tab gets selected and shows an overview of the system options.
Click Apply for the changes to take place.

section.title: Creating a robot controller from backup

wrapper.title: Creating a robot controller from backup for a robot controller

listitem.paragraph: In the Installation Manager window, select Controllers and then select Network tab.
Select your controller in the controller list and click Open. Installation Manager fetches information from the controller.
Click New, the Create New pane opens.
Enter the name of the robot controller in the Name box, and then click backup option under Create.
Click Select, the Select Backup pane opens, you can select the particular backup system and then click OK. If the right RobotWare already exists, then the version will be selected.

wrapper.paragraph: In the folder hierarchy of the backup path, the name of the valid backup system folder that must be selected will be set in bold. Similarly, names of all valid backup systems will be marked in bold in the folder hierarchy. User must select one of the valid backup folders for further system creation.

listitem.paragraph: Click Next. The Products tab gets selected. All products and add-ins that were part of the backup will be displayed here. You can add new/other product(s) and/or replace RobotWare version if needed.
Click Next. The Licenses tab gets selected. The license details of the backup will be displayed here. You are able to view the license(s) from the backup. Here you can add new/more licenses.
Click Next the Options tab gets selected, select/deselect options to customize them.
Click Next, the Confirmation tab gets selected and shows an overview of the system options.
Click Apply, the system gets created.

Once the installation completes, a Restart Controller dialog appears, click Yes to restart the controller. Click No to manually restart controller later, the controller stores the new system or changed system and these changes will take effect during the next restart.

wrapper.title: Creating a robot controller from backup for a virtual controller

listitem.paragraph: In the Installation Manager window, select Controllers and then select the Virtual tab. Here you are able to view the list of all virtual systems.
Click New, the Create New pane opens.
Enter the name of the system in the Name box, and then click backup option under Create.
Click Select, the Select Backup pane opens, you can select the particular backup system and then click OK.
If the right RobotWare already exists, then the version will be selected. If the RobotWare does not exist, click Replace to select the RobotWare.

wrapper.paragraph: In the folder hierarchy of the backup path, the name of the valid backup system folder that must be selected will be set in bold. Similarly, names of all valid backups will be marked in bold in the folder hierarchy. User must select one of the valid backup folders for further system creation.

listitem.paragraph: Click Next. The Products tab gets selected.
All products and add-ins that were part of the backups will be displayed here. You can add new/other product(s) and/or replace RobotWare if needed.
Click Next. The Licenses tab gets selected. Here you are able to view the license details of the backup.
Click Next, the Options tab gets selected, select/deselect options to customize them.
Click Next, the Confirmation tab gets selected and shows an overview of the system options.
Click Apply, the virtual controller gets created.

wrapper.title: Renaming a robot controller
wrapper.paragraph: You can rename a robot controller without re-installation.

listitem.paragraph: In the Installation Manager window, select Controllers and then select Network tab.
Select the active system which must be renamed.
Click Rename. The Rename System dialog appears.
In the Enter the new name for the system box, type in the new name.
Click Rename.

section.title: Using System Builder for managing RobotWare 5

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes how you create, build, modify and copy systems to run on virtual and robot controllers. These systems may even be converted to boot media and downloaded to a robot controller.

The system points out the robot models and options to use; it also stores configurations and programs for the robots. Therefore, it is good practice to use a unique system for each station even if the stations use the same basic setup. Otherwise, changes in one station may accidently overwrite data used in another station.
Use System Builder to create and modify systems based on RobotWare 5.xx. Use Installation Manager to create and modify systems with RobotWare versions 6.0 and later.

wrapper.title: About virtual and real systems System Builder about virtual and real systems
wrapper.paragraph: The system you run on virtual controllers can either be a real system built on real RobotWare keys or a virtual system built on virtual keys.

When using real systems, the RobotWare keys define which options and robot models shall be used, thus helping you to configure the system correctly. Real systems can be run both on virtual controllers and real IRC5 controllers.

When using virtual keys, all options and robot models are available, which is useful for evaluation purposes, but requires more configuration when creating the system. Systems built on virtual keys can only be run on virtual controllers.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: Creating a system entails applying a predefined template to a station, reusing an existing system or letting RobotStudio propose a system based on a layout.
To create a system, the following conditions must be met:

listitem.paragraph: The RobotWare media pool must be installed on your PC.

You must have a RobotWare key for the system, if creating a system to run on a robot controller. The RobotWare key is a license key that determines which robot models to use and which RobotWare options to run on the controller. The license key is delivered with the controller.

If you want to create a system for virtual use only, you can use a virtual key instead. Virtual keys are generated by the wizard. When using virtual keys, you select the robot models and options to use in the Modify Options section of the wizard.
Downloading to the robot controller requires a direct connection from your computer to the service or Ethernet port of the controller.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: All systems you create with the System Builder are stored locally on your computer. It is recommended that you store them in one or more dedicated system directories.

wrapper.title: Viewing system properties
wrapper.paragraph: To view system properties and add comments, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In the System Builder dialog box, select a system from the Systems box.
If necessary, in the System directory list, you can navigate to the folder in which your systems are stored.
The system properties are then displayed in the System Properties box. Optionally, type a comment in the Comments box, and click Save.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The New Controller System Wizard, used for building a new system, is launched from the System Builder.

wrapper.title: Starting the wizard
wrapper.paragraph: To start the wizard, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: Click System Builder to bring up a dialog box.
In the Actions group, click Create New. This starts the wizard.
Read the information on the welcome page and click Next.

wrapper.title: Specifying the name and location
wrapper.paragraph: To determine where on your computer to store the system you are creating, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In the Name box, enter a name for the system you are creating.
In the Path box, enter the path to the system directory in which you will store the system.
You can also click the Browse button and browse to the system directory.
Click Next.

wrapper.title: Entering the RobotWare keys
wrapper.paragraph: The RobotWare keys determine which RobotWare versions and parts to use in the system.

Creating a system to run on either IRC5 controllers or virtual controllers requires at least two keys: one for the controller module and one for each drive module in the cabinet. The keys are delivered together with the controller.

For creating a system to run on virtual controller only (for example, in Virtual IRC5), you can use virtual keys. Virtual keys give access to all options and robot models, but limits the use of the system to virtual controllers only.
To enter the key for the controller module, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller Key box, enter the controller key. You can also click Browse and browse to the key file. If creating a system for virtual use only, select the Virtual Key check box, and the controller key will be generated by the wizard.
In the Media Pool box, enter the path to the media pool. You can also click Browse and browse to the folder system.
In the RobotWare Version list, select which version of the RobotWare you want to use. Only RobotWare versions that are valid for the used key are available.
Click Next.

wrapper.title: Entering the drive keys
wrapper.paragraph: To enter the keys for the drive modules:

listitem.paragraph: In the Drive Key box, enter the key for the drive module. You can also click the Browse button and browse to the key file. If you used a virtual controller key, a virtual drive key is already generated by the wizard.
Click the right arrow button next to the Drive Key box. The key now appears in the Added drive keys list.
For real systems the drive key determines the connected robot model. For virtual systems you select the robot model in the Modify Options page. The default model is IRB140.
If you have a MultiMove system, repeat steps 1 and 2 for each drive key to add.

If you have a MultiMove system, make sure that the keys are numbered in the same way as their corresponding drive modules are connected to the controller module. Use the up and down arrows to rearrange the drive keys, if necessary.
If you want to create the system as it is now, click Finish.
If you want to modify options, or add options, parameter data or additional files to the home directory, click Next.

wrapper.title: Adding additional options
wrapper.paragraph: Here you can add options, such as external axes and dispense applications, that are not included in the basic system. Options require a license key and must be first imported to the media pool. To add additional options, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In the Key box, enter the option key. You can also click the Browse button and browse to the option's key file.
Click the Arrow button.
The option that the key unlocks is now displayed in the Added Options list.

wrapper.paragraph: If several versions of an additional option exists, only the latest version can be selected. To use an older version, remove the other versions of the additional option from the Mediapool.

System Builder can modify a system only when all referenced additional options and RobotWare mediapool are placed in the same folder. It is not possible to modify a system that uses a mediapool embedded in a Pack and Go file. You must copy the mediapool to a common mediapool folder and create a system from backup.

listitem.paragraph: Repeat steps 1 and 2 for all options you want to include.
Choose whether you want to create the system as it is now, or to continue with the wizard.
If you want to create the system as it is now, click Finish.
If you want to modify options, or add parameter data or additional files to the home directory, click Next.

wrapper.title: Modifying options
wrapper.paragraph: Here you can set up and configure the options in your system. For virtual robot systems, you also select the robot models to use. To modify any options, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In the Option tree, expand the option folders to the level where you find the option you want to modify.
Only the options unlocked by the used keys are available.
Modify the option.
Repeat steps 1 and 2 for all options you want to modify.
Choose whether you want to create the system as it is now, or to continue with the wizard.
If you want to create the system as it is now, click Finish.
If you want to add parameter data or additional files to the home directory, click Next.

wrapper.title: Adding parameter data
wrapper.paragraph: Parameter data is stored in the parameter data files (.cfg files). Each parameter topic has its own parameter file. You can add only one parameter file for each topic. To add parameter data, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In the Parameter data box, enter the path to the folder for the parameter data files. You can also click the Browse button and browse to the folder.
In the list of parameter data files, select the file you want to include and press the Arrow button. Repeat for all files you want to include.
The included parameter data files will now appear in the Added parameter data files list.
Repeat steps 1 and 2 for each parameter data file you want to add.
Choose whether you want to create the system as it is now, or to continue with the wizard.
If you want to create the system as it is now, click Finish.
If you want to add additional files to the home directory, click Next.

wrapper.title: Adding files to the home directory
wrapper.paragraph: You can add any type of file to the systemâs home directory. When the system is loaded to a controller, these files will also be loaded. To add files to the system's home directory, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In the Files box, enter the path to the folder for the files you want to include. You can also click the Browse button and browse to the folder.
In the list of files, select the file to add and click the Arrow button. Repeat for all files you want to add.
The added files will now appear in the Added files list.
Choose whether you want to create the system as it is now, or to continue with the wizard.
If you want to create the system as it is now, click Finish.
If you want to read a summary before you create the system, click Next.

wrapper.title: Completing the New Controller System Wizard
wrapper.paragraph: To complete the wizard, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: Read the system summary.
If the system is OK, click Finish.
If the system is not OK, click Back and make modifications or corrections.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The Modify Controller System Wizard, used to modify existing systems, is launched from the System Builder. The wizard helps you with tasks like changing robots, adding and removing external axes and other options. A system that is running must be first shut down before modification.

wrapper.title: Starting the wizard
wrapper.paragraph: To start the wizard when creating a new station:

listitem.paragraph: If the system is currently running, on the Controller menu, point to Shutdown and then click Shutdown.
On the Controller menu, click System Builder to bring up a dialog box.
In the System directory list, enter or browse to the system directory. Select a system from the list beneath, review the system properties and add and save any comments.
In the Actions group, click Modify. This starts the wizard.
Read the information on the welcome page and click Next.

wrapper.title: Modifying the program revision
wrapper.paragraph: The RobotWare versions that are available for the system are determined by the controller key. The key is essential to the system and cannot be modified.
To use another RobotWare version than the available ones, create a new system with another key.
To optionally modify the program revision, follow the appropriate step or steps:

listitem.paragraph: To keep the current RobotWare version, select Yes and then click Next.
To replace the current RobotWare version, Select No, replace it.
In the Media pool box, enter the path to the media pool. You can also click the Browse button and browse to the folder.
In the New program revision box, select which version of RobotWare you want to use. Only RobotWare versions that are valid for the RobotWare key are available.
Click Next.

wrapper.title: Adding or removing drive keys
wrapper.paragraph: The drive key corresponds to the drive modules in your controller. For MultiMove systems, you have one drive module (and one key) for each robot. The keys for your system are delivered together with the controller.

The system is created with a virtual robot controller key, virtual drive keys are generated by the wizard. When you have added one virtual drive key for each robot, you select which robot to use for each key on the Modify Options page.
To optionally add or remove the keys for the drive modules, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: To add a key for a drive module, enter the key in the Enter Drive Key box. You can also click the Browse button and browse to the key file.
Click the right arrow button. The key now appears in the Added drive key list.
If you have a MultiMove system, repeat steps 1 and 2 for each drive key to add.
To remove a drive module, select the corresponding key in the Added drive key list and click Remove drive key.
If you have a MultiMove system, repeat step 3 for each drive key to remove.

If you have a MultiMove system, make sure that the keys are numbered in the same way as their corresponding drive modules are connected to the controller module. Use the up and down arrows to rearrange the drive keys, if necessary.
Choose whether you want to create the system as it is now, or to continue with the wizard.
If you want to create the system as it is now, click Finish.
If you want to modify options, parameter data or add files to or remove files from the home directory, click Next.

wrapper.title: Adding or removing additional options
wrapper.paragraph: To optionally add or remove additional options:

listitem.paragraph: To add an add-in, in the Enter Key box, enter the option key. You can also click the Browse button and browse to the option's key file.
Click the Arrow button.
The option that the key unlocks is now displayed in the Added Options list.

wrapper.paragraph: If several versions of an additional option exists, only the latest version can be selected. To use an older version, remove the other versions of the additional option from the Mediapool.

listitem.paragraph: Repeat steps 1 and 2 for all options you want to include.
To remove an add-in, In the additional options, in the Added options list, select the add-in you want to remove.
Click Remove.
Choose whether you want to create the system as it is now, or to continue with the wizard.
If you want to create the system as it is now, click Finish.
If you want to modify parameter data or add files to or remove files from the home directory, click Next.

wrapper.title: Modifying options
wrapper.paragraph: To optionally modify any options, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In the Option tree, expand the option folders to the level where you find the option you want to modify.
Only the options unlocked by the used keys are available.
Modify the option.
Repeat steps 1 and 2 for all options you want to modify.
Choose whether you want to create the system as it is now, or to continue with the wizard.
If you want to create the system as it is now, click Finish.
If you want to modify parameter data or add files to or remove files from the home directory, click Next.

wrapper.title: Adding or removing parameter data
wrapper.paragraph: Parameter data is stored in the parameter data files (.cfg files). Each parameter topic has its own parameter file. You can add only one parameter file for each topic. To add or remove parameter data, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: To add parameter data, in the Parameter data box, enter the path to the folder for the parameter data files. You can also click the Browse button and browse to the folder.
In the list of parameter data files, select the file you want to include and press the Arrow button. Repeat for all files you want to include.
The included parameter data files will now appear in the Added parameter data files list.
Repeat steps 1 and 2 for each parameter data file you want to add.
To remove parameter data, in the Added parameter data files list, select the parameter data file to remove.
Click Remove.
Choose whether you want to create the system as it is now, or to continue with the wizard.
If you want to create the system as it is now, click Finish.
If you want to add to or remove files from the home directory, click Next.

wrapper.title: Add files to or remove files from the home directory
wrapper.paragraph: You can add any type of file to the systemâs home directory, or remove files from it. When the system is loaded to a controller, these files will also be loaded. To optionally add files to or remove files from the system's home directory, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: To add files, in the Files box, enter the path to the folder for the files you want to include. You can also click the Browse button and browse to the folder.
In the list of files, select the file to add and click the Arrow button. Repeat for all files you want to add.
The added files will now appear in the Added files list.
To remove files, in the Added files list, select the file to remove.
Click Remove.
Choose whether you want to create the system as it is now, or to continue with the wizard.
If you want to create the system as it is now, click Finish.
If you want to read a summary before you create the system, click Next.

wrapper.title: Complete the Modify Controller System wizard
wrapper.paragraph: To complete the wizard, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: Read the system summary.
If the system is OK, click Finish.
If the system is not OK, click Back and make modifications or corrections.

wrapper.title: Result
wrapper.paragraph: Modifications will take effect when the wizard is completed.
If the system has been downloaded to a controller, it must be downloaded again before the modifications will take effect on the controller.
If the system is used by a virtual controller, restart the controller using the restart mode Reset controller for the changes to take effect.

wrapper.title: Deleting a system
wrapper.paragraph: To delete a system, follow this steps:

listitem.paragraph: From the System Builder dialog box, select the system and then click Delete.

wrapper.title: Copy a system
wrapper.paragraph: To copy a system, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: From the System Builder dialog box, select the system and then click Copy to bring up a dialog box.
Enter a name for the new system and a path, and then click OK.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The Create System from Backup Wizard, which creates a new system from a controller system backup, is launched from the System Builder. In addition, you can change the program revision and options.

wrapper.title: Starting the wizard
wrapper.paragraph: To start the wizard, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: From the System Builder dialog box, click Create from Backup. This starts the wizard.
Read the information on the welcome page and click Next.

wrapper.title: Specifying the name and location
wrapper.paragraph: To specify the destination folder, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In the Name box, enter a name for the system you are creating.
In the Path box, enter the path to the system directory in which you will store the system.
You can also click the Browse button and browse to the system directory.
Click Next.

wrapper.title: Locating the backup
wrapper.paragraph: To locate a system from backup, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In the Backup folder box, enter the path to the backup folder. Alternatively, click the Browse button to browse to it. Click Next.
In the Media Pool box, enter the path to the media pool containing the appropriate RobotWare program. Confirm the backup information that now appears in the wizard. Click Next.

section.title: Downloading a system to a controller

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: All systems you access from the System Builder are stored on your computer. If you wish to run a system on a robot controller, you must first load it to the controller, which then requires a restart.

wrapper.title: Load a system
wrapper.paragraph: To load a system to a controller, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph:
From the System Builder dialog box, select a system and then click Download to Controller System Builder download a system to controller
to bring up a dialog box.

wrapper.paragraph: Systems with incompatible hardware versions will not be displayed in the Download to Controller dialog box.

listitem.paragraph: Specify the Destination Controller for the system.

paragraph.bold: You can select by using the...

td.paragraph: the controller has been detected automatically.
Specify IP address or controller name option
your PC and the robot is connected to the same network.
You can only use the controller name in DHCP networks.
your PC is directly connected to the controller's service port.

listitem.paragraph: Optionally, click Test Connection to confirm that the connection between the computer and the Controller is OK.
Click Load.
Answer Yes to the question Do you want to restart the controller now?

td.paragraph: The controller restarts immediately and the downloaded system starts automatically.
The controller does not restart immediately.
To start using the downloaded system, you have to:

listitem.paragraph: Restart the controller using the restart mode Start Boot Application.
Select the system manually.

td.paragraph: The downloaded system is removed from the controller.

section.title: Examples using the System Builder when offline
A system with support for one robot and one positioner external axis

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: In this example we will use the System Builder to create an offline system to use in a new RobotStudio station with one IRB1600 robot and one IRBP 250D positioner external axis.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: When creating systems for positioner external axes, you need the media pool and the license key file for that specific positioner. In this example we will use a media pool and license key file for a demo positioner.
Paths to files and folders assume that RobotStudio and the RobotWare media pool have been installed at their default locations on Windows XP. If not, adjust the paths accordingly.

wrapper.title: Starting the New Controller System Wizard
wrapper.paragraph: To create a system like the one described above, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: Click System Builder to bring up a dialog box.
In the dialog box, click Create New to bring up the New Controller System Wizard.
Read the welcome text, and click Next to continue to the next page.
Select the Virtual key check box. A virtual controller key now appears in the Controller Key box. In this example we will use the default media pool and RobotWare version.
Click Next to continue to the next page.
Click the Right Arrow button next to the Enter Drive key box to create one drive key for the robot.
Click Next to continue to the next page.

wrapper.title: Adding options
wrapper.paragraph: This is where we point out the key file for the positioner.

listitem.paragraph: Next to the Enter key box, click the browse button and select the key file.
In this example, browse to and select the file extkey.kxt in the folder C:\Program Files\ABB Industrial IT\Robotics IT\MediaPool\3HEA-000-00022.01.

wrapper.paragraph: In the MediaPool folder media pools for several standard positioners are installed. They are named by the positionerâs article number, with a suffix that indicates if it is configured for single-robot or MultiMove systems.

listitem.paragraph: Click the Right Arrow button next to the Enter key box to add the key for the positioner.
Click Next and continue to the next page of the wizard.

wrapper.title: Modifying options
wrapper.paragraph: When creating robot systems from real robot keys, the key sets the options. But since we are using a virtual key, we have to set the options manually. To set the options necessary for a positioner, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: Scroll down to the RobotWare / Hardware group and select the 709-x DeviceNet check box.
This option is for the communication between the controller and the track external axis.
Scroll down to the DriveModule1 / Drive module application group and expand the ABB Standard manipulator option. Select the IRB 1600 option.
This option sets the robot to an IRB 1600-5/1.2.

Scroll down to the DriveModule1 > Drive module configuration group; select the Drive System 04 1600/2400/260 option; expand the Additional axes drive module group and select the R2C2 Add drive option.
Expand the Drive type in position Z4 group and select the 753-1 Drive C in pos Z4 option
Expand the Drive type in position Y4 group and select the754-1 Drive C in pos Y4 option
Expand the Drive type in position X4 group and select the755-1 Drive C in pos X4 option
This option adds drive modules for the positioner axes.

wrapper.paragraph: When using the latest drive system, do the following:

Scroll down to the DriveModule1 > Drive module configuration group; select the Drive System 09 120/140/1400/1600 Compact option; expand the Power supply configuration group and select 1-Phase Power supply or 3-Phase Power supply (as applicable) > Additional axes drive module > Additional drive

listitem.paragraph: Expand the Drive type in position X3 group and select the Drive ADU-790A in position X3 option
Expand the Drive type in position Y3 group and select the Drive ADU-790A in position Y3 option
Expand the Drive type in position Z3 group and select the Drive ADU-790A in position Z3 option

Click Finish and the system will be created. When starting the system in a RobotStudio station, you have to set up the system to load a model for the positioner and to get the motions to work properly.

section.title: Options settings for systems with positioners

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This is an overview of the RobotWare options to set when creating a system for positioner external axes. Note that besides setting the RobotWare options, you must add an additonal option key for the positioner.

wrapper.title: Media pools and option keys for the positioners
wrapper.paragraph: If you have the media pool and option key for your positioner, you can use these files.

If not, media pools for standard positioners are installed with RobotStudio. The path to these media pools in a default installation is: C.\program files\ABB Industrial IT\Robotics IT\MediaPool. In this folder a media pool for each positioner is located. These are named by the article number of the positioner, with a suffix that indicates if it is configured for a single-robot or a MultiMove system.
In the Additional option page of the System Builder, you should add the option for the positioner by opening the mediapool folder for the positioner to add and selecting the extkey.kxt file.

wrapper.title: Options for positioners in single-robot systems
wrapper.paragraph: When adding a positioner to a single-robot system, the positioner will be added to the same task as the robot. Below, the options to set on the Modify Options page of the System Builder for such a system are listed:

listitem.paragraph: RobotWare > Hardware > 709-x DeviceNet > 709-1 Master/Slave Single
Optionally, for using the system with ArcWare also add RobotWare > Application arc > 633-1 Arc
DriveModule 1 > Drive module configuration > Drive System 04 1600/2400/260 > RC2C Add drive > 753-1 Drive C in pos Z4 > 754-2 Drive T in pos Y4 > 755-3 Drive U in pos X4

wrapper.title: Options for positioners in MultiMove robot systems
wrapper.paragraph: When adding a positioner to a MultiMove robot system, the positioner shall be added to a task of its own (thus you also have to add a drive key for the positioner). Below, the options to set on the Modify Options page of the System Builder for such a system are listed:

listitem.paragraph: RobotWare > Hardware > 709-x DeviceNet > 709-1 Master/Slave Single
RobotWare > Motion coordinated part 1 > 604-1 MultiMove Coordinated Optionally, expand the MultiMove Coordinated option and select process options for the robots.
Optionally, for using the system with ArcWare, add RobotWare > Application Arc > 633-1 Arc

DriveModule 1 > Drive module configuration > Drive System 04 1600/2400/260 > RC2C Add drive > 753-1 Drive C in pos Z4 > 754-2 Drive T in pos Y4 > 755-3 Drive U in pos X4. For the other drive modules, no additional axes should be configured.

section.title: A MultiMove system with two coordinated robots
Creating a coordinated system using System Builder

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: In this example we will use the System Builder to create a coordinated offline system with one IRB2400 and one IRB1600 robot to use in a new RobotStudio station.

wrapper.title: Starting the New Controller System Wizard
wrapper.paragraph: To create a system like the one described above, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: Click System Builder to bring up the dialog box.
In the dialog box, click Create New to bring up the New Controller System Wizard.
Read the welcome text, and click Next to continue to the next page.
In the Name box, enter the name of the system. The name must not contain blank spaces or non-ASCII characters.
In this example, name the system MyMultiMove.
In the Path box, enter the path for the folder to save the system in, or click the Browse button to browse to the folder or create a new one.
In this example, save the system in C:\Program Files\ABB\RobotStudio\ABB Library\Training Systems.
Click Next to continue to the next page.
Select the Virtual key check box. A virtual controller key now appears in the Controller Key box. In this example we will use the default media pool and RobotWare version.
Click Next to continue to the next page.
Click the Right Arrow button next to the Enter Drive key box twice to create one drive key for each robot.
Click Next to continue to the next page.

wrapper.title: Adding options
wrapper.paragraph: This system does not require any additional option keys. Click Next and continue to the next page of the wizard.

wrapper.title: Modifying options
wrapper.paragraph: When creating robot systems from robot keys, the key sets the options. But since we are using a virtual key, we have to set the options manually.
When creating a system for several manipulators (up to four), you must include either of the RobotWare options MultiMove Independent, or MultiMove Coordinated for the related motion tasks to start.
It is recommended to use the System From Layout function when you create robot systems for RobotStudio. Then the MultiMove option gets added automatically.
To set the options necessary for a MultiMove, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: Scroll down to the RobotWare / Motion Coordination part 1 group and select the MultiMove Coordinated check box.
Scroll down to the RobotWare/ Engineering Tools group and select the Multitasking check box.

wrapper.paragraph: The option Advanced RAPID is included in RobotWare- operating system from RobotWare 5.60 and later.

listitem.paragraph: Scroll down to the DriveModule1 / Drive module application group and expand the ABB Standard manipulator option. Select the IRB 2400 Type A option, manipulator variant IRB 2400L Type A.
Scroll down to the DriveModule2 / Drive module application group and expand the ABB Standard manipulator option. Select the IRB 1600 option, manipulator variant IRB 1600-5/1.2.
Click Finish and the system will be created.

section.title: Creating a coordinated system using Installation Manager

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: In this example we will use the Installation Manager to create a coordinated offline system to use in a new RobotStudio station.

wrapper.title: Creating a coordinated system
wrapper.paragraph: To create a system like the one described above, follow these steps:

listitem.paragraph: In Installation Manager, in the Controllers page select a system and click Next.
In the Product page, click Add, the Select Product dialog box is displayed.
Select the required product and click OK.
Select the added product and click Next.
In the Licenses page, select the required license and click Next.
In the Options page, under the System Options tab, select the Motion Coordination > Multimove Options > 604-1 MultiMove Coordinated check box. The Engineering Tools option will auto-expand.
Under the Engineering Tools option, select the required check boxes and click Next.
In the Confirmation page, review the system configuration and click Apply, to create the system.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The controller configuration is a collection of six topics, each describing a configuration area of the controller. A controller is configured at the factory as per the RobotWare options that are selected at the time of delivery. The factory default configuration is altered only during an update or any alteration processes. The configuration parameters can be saved as text files (*.cfg) that lists the values of system parameters. If the parameter is assigned the default value, then it will not be listed in the configuration file.

When creating a backup of the controller, the configuration files will be stored in the SYSPAR folder of the backup file structure. The configuration files will be loaded into the controller memory when the backup is restored.

The controller system folder contains the SYSPAR folder in ...\MySystem\SYSPAR\ location. The configuration files in this folder gets loaded when the controller resets. Note that changes to the configuration and RAPID will be discarded during a controller reset. Configuration changes which are related to the installation and independent of the program being executed can be loaded from the SYSPAR folder. Examples of folders that can be loaded are configuration of background tasks and the corresponding RAPID modules.

td.paragraph: Functions to simplify working with the virtual controller

wrapper.paragraph: A topic is a collection of system parameters of the same type. It represents a configuration area of the controller. A separate configuration file is saved for each topic, it can also be generated while creating a backup. Type holds the parameter definition. The parameter values are normally predefined at delivery. The values are restricted to data type, and sometimes to be within an interval. An instance is a user defined variable of the selected type. In some cases system parameters, depending on their values, are further structured into subparameters, also called arguments or action values. The following image shows the details of the I/O signal, di2.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=4.983in 1.271in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

wrapper.paragraph: System parameters are configured using RobotStudio or the FlexPendant.

listitem.paragraph: To view the topics of a controller, from the Controller tab, expand the Configuration node of the controller.
All topics are now displayed as child nodes of the Configuration node.
To view the types and instances of a topic, double-click the required topic node.
The Configuration Editor opens and lists all types of the topic in the Type name list. In the Instance list, rows display the selected type and columns display parameter values of the instances.
To view detailed parameter information of an instance, double-click the instance.
The instance editor displays the current value, restrictions and limits of each parameter in the instance.

wrapper.paragraph: Virtual networks, devices and signals contained in the EIO.cfg file can be viewed the I/O System node in the Controller browser.

Use the Configuration Editor to select a configuration type and to create a new instance of the type, for example, adding a new instance of the type Signal creates a new signal in the virtual controller.

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller tab, expand the Controller and the Configuration node and double-click the topic that contains the type to add an instance. This opens the Configuration Editor.
In the Type name list, select the type to add an instance.
Double-click the type, the corresponding window opens to the right hand side.
Right-click any element, and click Edit Tasks.
On the Controller menu, point to Configuration and click Add type (the word type is replaced by the type that was selected earlier).
Right-click anywhere in the configuration editor and then select Add type from the shortcut menu.
A new instance with default values gets added and displayed in the Instance Editor window.
Click OK to save the new instance.

The values in the new instance are now validated. If the values are valid, the instance gets saved, else a notification on the incorrect parameter values gets displayed. Certain changes take effect only after a controller restart.
In the Controller tab, expand the Controller and the Configuration node and double-click the topic that contains the instance to copy. This opens the Configuration Editor.
In the Type name list of the Configuration Editor, select the type to copy an instance.
Right--click the selected row, and then click Copy and change the name of the instance. Click OK.
To select multiple instances, in the Instance list, select several instances to copy.
The parameter values of all selected instances must be identical, else the default values will be absent in the parameters of the new instances.
On the Controller menu, point to Configuration and click Copy Type (the word type is replaced by the type that was selected earlier).
Right-click the instance to copy and then select Copy Type from the shortcut menu.
A new instance with the same values as the one that was copied gets added and displayed in the Instance Editor window.
Change the name of the instance and click OK to save the new instance.

The values in the new instance are now validated. If the values are valid, the instance gets saved, else a notification on the incorrect parameter values gets displayed. Certain changes take effect only after a controller restart.
In the Controller tab, expand the Controller and the Configuration node and double-click the topic that contains the type of which you want to delete an instance. This opens the Configuration Editor.
In the Type name list of the Configuration Editor, select the type of which you want to delete an instance.
In the Instance list, select the instance to delete.
On the Controller menu, point to Configuration and then click Delete type (the word type is replaced by the type you selected previously).
You can also right-click the instance to delete and then select Delete type from the shortcut menu.
A message box is displayed, asking if you want to delete or keep the instance. Click Yes to confirm that you want to delete it.

The values in the new instance are now validated. If the values are valid, the instance gets saved, else a notification on the incorrect parameter values gets displayed. Certain changes take effect only after a controller restart.

wrapper.paragraph: The system parameters of a configuration topic can be saved to a configuration file, stored on the PC or any of its network drives.
The configuration files can then be loaded into a controller. They are thereby useful as backups, or for transferring configurations from one controller to another.

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller tab, expand the Configuration node and select the topic to save to a file.
On the Controller menu, point to Configuration and select Save Parameters.
You can also right-click the topic and then select Save System Parameters from the shortcut menu.
In the Save As dialog box, browse for the folder to save the file in.
Click Save.
In the Controller tab, select the Configuration node.
On the Controller menu, point to Configuration and click Save System Parameters.
You can also right-click the configuration node and then click Save System Parameters.
In the Save System Parameters dialog box, select the topics to save to files. Then click Save.
In the Browse for Folder dialog box, browse for the folder to save the files in, and then click OK.
The selected topics will now be saved as configuration files with default names in the specified folder.

wrapper.paragraph: A configuration file contains the system parameters of a configuration topic. They are thereby useful as backups, or for transferring configurations from one controller to another. When loading a configuration file to a controller, it must be of the same major version as the controller. For instance, you cannot load configuration files from an S4 system to an IRC5 controller.

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller tab, select the Configuration node.
On the Controller menu, point to Configuration and select Load Parameters.
Alternatively, right-click the configuration node and then select Load Parameters from the context menu. This opens the Select mode dialog box.
In the Select mode dialog box, select the following options:
Select Delete existing parameters before loading to replace the entire configuration of the topic with the one in the configuration file.
Click Load parameters if no duplicates to add new parameters from the configuration file to the topic, without modifying the existing ones.

Click Load parameters and replace duplicates to add new parameters from the configuration file to the topic and update the existing ones with values from the configuration file. Parameters that exist only in the controller and not in the configuration file will remain.
Click Open and browse to the configuration file to load. Then click Open again.
In the information box, click OK to load the parameters from the configuration file.
After loading the configuration file, close the Select mode dialog box.
Certain changes take effect only after a controller restart.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Signal Analyzer is used to record robot signals from robot or virtual controllers. The version of Signal Analyzer used for robot controllers is called Signal Analyzer Online.

listitem.paragraph: To open Signal Analyzer, on the Simulation tab, in the Signal Analyzer group, click Signal Analyzer.
To open Signal Analyzer Online, on the Controller tab, in the Controller Tools group, click Signal Analyzer Online.

wrapper.title: Significance of signal analyzer
wrapper.paragraph: The data from the Signal Analyzer can be used to fine-tune robot behavior for optimizing robot performance during production. For example, if the robot is working with a continuous process where constant speed is the critical parameter, then the Signal Analyzer can be used to monitor the speed signals from the robot motion system. Constant monitoring helps in identifying any speed fluctuations which can be traced to the corresponding line in the RAPID code that causes the speed fluctuations. After identifying the root cause of the fluctuations, the robot program can be edited to rectify these issues.

Another example where Signal Analyzer can be used is cable simulation, where the physics signals monitor the cable tension, length and twist. These signals can be used for identifying the wear and tear of cables. Based on these signal data, the cable (routing, length) and the program can be altered to reduce wear.

Signal analyzer can only monitor a group of selected signals. This selection varies for robot controller and virtual controller. The following table provides the list of signals for robot and virtual controllers that can be monitored in signal analyzer.

td.paragraph: Target Changed1 , Tool Changed, Workobject Changed
Pos X, Y, Z in Current Workobject
Robot Configuration cf1, cf4, cf6, cfx

wrapper.paragraph: Stress Index estimation is supported only for 57x0, 67x0 and 77x0 for OmniCore.

td.paragraph: Cable tension, cable length and cable twist (only available for stations with cables)
All signals, available only for virtual controllers.

paragraph.italic: 1. The Target Changed event data do not represent the current target, instead it represents the subsequent target.

2. Signal for assessing the amount of stress that the joints are subjected to. Monitoring this signal helps in comparative analyses between different options of cycles to reduce the mean value of the signal rather than removing individual maximum values. This signal can also be used to compare the same cycle on different robots. This signal has no unit of measurement and depends on how hard the robot is run relative to the gear on the axis. For a stationary axis, the Stress Index signal value is zero. The maximum value of Stress Index signal is 110.
3. The Maximum Stress Index signal has the value of the Stress Index Jx signal with the highest value at each point in time.

4. Shows the Power Supply utilization as a percentage of the controllerâs power supply. Use this signal to see if there is capacity left for an external equipment, or to assess the need for another controller variant.

wrapper.title: Stop distance estimation
wrapper.paragraph: These signals show the stop distance of the robot during a stop category 0 or stop category 1. For example, if the stop distance signal for joint J1 is 7 degrees at time=48 ms, it means that J1 will move 7 degrees in positive direction if the robot is stopped at t=48 ms.

The measurement and calculation of overall stopping performance for a robot must be tested with its correct load, speed, and tools, in its actual environment, before the robot is taken into production, see ISO 13855:2010.

wrapper.title: Total Motor Power
wrapper.paragraph: The Total Motor Power signal shows the total instantaneous power for each joint. It may be positive or negative.

The instantaneous power for a specific joint is positive when it accelerates and negative when it decelerates. If one joint is accelerating at the same time as another joint is decelerating, then the negative energy from the decelerating joint is reused by the accelerating joint. If the sum of the instantaneous power of all joints is negative then the power surplus is either fed back to grid or burned off in the bleeder.

For a virtual robot the signal is based on a nominal robot during typical conditions, for a robot the signal is based on the torque for that particular robot in the actual conditions. For a robot the value of the motor power signal depends on various factors, for example, the temperature of the robot and the length of the cables.

Total Motor Power signal represents the power consumed by the mechanical robot arm and not the power that is fed into the controller cabinet from the power network. The power used by the controller cabinet is excluded.

wrapper.title: Total Motor Energy
wrapper.paragraph: The Total Motor Energy signal is the integration of the power over time. The Total Motor Energy signal includes negative Total Motor Power signal when the controller supports refeeding of power.

listitem.paragraph: For OmniCore controllers with version earlier than 7.10, Total Motor Energy signal is not decreased in RobotStudio even if there is a power surplus.
For OmniCore controllers with version 7.10 or later, Total Motor Energy signal is decreased in RobotStudio when there is a power surplus.

wrapper.title: Purpose of signals
wrapper.paragraph: The purpose of the Total Motor Power and Total Motor Energy signals is to provide an estimate of the power and energy used by the robots. For virtual robots, these signals can be used to identify peaks in the power usage to enable the robot programmer to adjust the robot program with the aim to reduce the power consumption. For robots, the signals can be used to compare the power usage of different robot individuals running the same robot program, to see if any robot differs significantly from the others. Any such deviation may indicate that the robot needs maintenance.

wrapper.title: Near Limit
wrapper.paragraph: Near Limit checks the distance to the closest limit for each joint. If any joint is less than 20 degrees from a limit, the Near Limit signal will show the current value. Otherwise, the value of the signal will be constant at 20 degrees. If more than one joint is below 20 degrees from a limit, then the one that is closest will be looked at.

wrapper.title: Recording signals for a virtual controller
wrapper.paragraph: Before starting signal analyzer, choose the signals that must be recorded in the Signal Setup window.

listitem.paragraph: Load a station with a virtual controller.
In the Simulation tab, in the Signal Analyzer group, click Signal Setup.
The Signal Setup window appears.
In the Signals view, select the signals to be recorded during simulation.
The selected signals are added to the Selection view.
The signal recording can be set to start with the simulation. To enable signal recording during simulation, in the Signal Analyzer group, select Enabled.
The signal data from each signal recording session is saved. To view the signal recording, in the Signal Analyzer group, click Recordings.

wrapper.paragraph: To add the joint position signals of mechanical units to the signal recording, select Signal Setup and then select Quick add position signals. Use the Recording Playback feature to view the recorded signals.

wrapper.title: Recording signals for a robot controller
wrapper.paragraph: RobotStudio must be connected to a robot controller for using the following procedure.

listitem.paragraph: On the Controller tab, in the Controller Tools group, click Signal Analyzer Online and then click Signal Setup. The Signal Setup window opens.
In the Signals view, select the signals that must be recorded during simulation.
The selected signals are added to the Selection view.
Start the simulation, and then in the Controller Tools group, click Signal Analyzer Online and then click Start Recording.
To stop recording, in the Controller Tools group, click Signal Analyzer Online and then click Stop Recording.
The signal data from each signal recording session is saved. To view the signal recording, in the Signal Analyzer group, click Recordings.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The saved signal recordings of the current station are stored in the following locations.

listitem.paragraph: In the RobotStudio documents folder:
C:\Users\<user name>\Documents\RobotStudio\SignalAnalyzer\Stations for a virtual controller and C:\Users\<user name>\Documents\RobotStudio\SignalAnalyzer\Online for a robot controller.
In the Project folder for the respective project:
C:\Users\<user name>\Documents\RobotStudio\Projects\<Project folder>\SignalAnalyzer.

wrapper.paragraph: The signal recordings can be exported in the following formats:

listitem.paragraph: RobotStudio Signal Recording (*.rssigdata).
Excel Workbook (*.xlsx).
Text (Tab delimited) (*.txt).

wrapper.paragraph: The signal recordings can be imported in the RobotStudio Signal Recording (*.rssigdata) format.

wrapper.title: Using the recording play back feature
wrapper.paragraph: It is possible to record and view the joint position signals of mechanical units. Use the following procedure to record and then play back the signal recording of joint position signals.

listitem.paragraph: To add the joint position signals of mechanical units to the signal recording, in the Signal Analyzer group, click Signal Setup and then click Quick add position signals.
In the Simulation Control group, Click Play to record the simulation.
In the Signal Analyzer group, click Playback. The Recording Playback tab gets displayed.
In the Recording: list, select the required file and then click Play to view the recording.
Use the buttons in the Recording Playback tab to navigate through the recording during play back.

wrapper.paragraph: Use the following check-boxes to enhance play back visualization.

td.paragraph: View a semitransparent robot that moves along the stop category 0 positions.
View a semitransparent robot that moves along the stop category 1 positions.
Export a recording with joint signals to a 3D animation in glTF (.glb) format.
SafeMove zones and geometries can be included if Visual SafeMove is open.

Creates a new part based on the current recording that represents the approximate total volume of the robot and tool movement along a path. This will help in assessing collisions between the environment and the volume. These parts can be exported in polygon formats such as, glTF, STL, VRML and so on, but CAD formats are not supported.

Construct from interpolated positions: Creates a point cloud with extra points added to compensate for the discrete nature of the recording, then use an algorithm to construct a volumetric polygon mesh from the point cloud. The resultant volume will be rough and contains significantly less polygons and avoids discretization holes.

Combine discrete positions: Creates a single part combining the robot geometry in each discrete position of the recording. The part is processed to remove redundant polygons. The resultant volume will be bigger(greater memory usage) than the volume created using the Construct from interpolated positions option. While creating volume using this option, discrete positions only are included, hence, the result can contain holes especially when the speed is high.

wrapper.paragraph: The RAM usage can be significantly high for longer recordings.

paragraph.bold: Enable measurement on stop position graphics

td.paragraph: Enable measurement on the semitransparent robot.

paragraph.bold: Click on robot, tool or tooldata to measure stop distance

td.paragraph: Measure the distance between a selected point on the robot and the corresponding stop position on the semitransparent robot.

paragraph.bold: Use stop position in collision detection

td.paragraph: Detect collision using the stop category 0 or stop category 1 positions.

wrapper.title: Accessing the RAPID code from signal recording
wrapper.paragraph: Signal recordings are analyzed to find the root-cause of any unexpected robot events. From signal analyzer, it is possible to open the RAPID module that causes this robot event. Use the following procedure to access the RAPID code from signal analyzer. The Target Changed event must be recorded for using the following procedure.
The Target Changed event data do not represent the current target, instead it represents the subsequent target.

listitem.paragraph: In the Recordings window, right-click the signal recording and then click Open.
The Signal Analyzer window opens with the selected signal recording.
Scroll down and access the Events table, and click the required RAPID event to view the Current Target details.
Click the Location link to open the respective RAPID module.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: RobotStudio is designed to work with one robot controller at a time. Use Jobs function to perform certain actions on a large population of robot controllers. Fleet or device set is a collection of selected set of controllers in a network that are identified by the IP Address or the DNS name. A Job is defined by a Device list and an Action. Action will be carried out for the selected controllers in the Device list.

The default set of actions are designed to monitor and to collect data from the controllers in the device list. This data can be analyzed for error detection and further rectification for maintaining uniform configuration across all controllers in a fleet.

wrapper.title: Jobs tab
wrapper.paragraph: The Jobs feature is managed from the Jobs contextual tab. On the Controller tab, in the Controller Tools group, click Jobs to open the Jobs Contextual tab.
The Jobs contextual tab contains the following groups.

td.paragraph: A user-defined group of robot controllers for applying a job. Device lists can be reused between jobs.
A command group containing various job options.

wrapper.title: Device Lists group
wrapper.paragraph: The Device Lists group contains the following commands and controls.

td.paragraph: Opens a new empty device list window for creating a new group of robot controllers.
Opens a previously saved device list to edit or review.
Saves the contents of an active device list window to disk in .xlsx format. These files can be edited in Microsoft Excel without changing the grid structure.
Populates the active device list window with all controllers that Netscan finds on the local subnet.

wrapper.title: Jobs group
wrapper.paragraph: The Jobs group contains the following commands and controls.

td.paragraph: Provides options, Save Job and Edit Job Templates.

listitem.paragraph: Save Job : Saves the job specification as an .xml file.
Edit Job Templates: Allows you to edit an existing template file.

td.paragraph: Verifies the status of the group of robot controllers.

wrapper.title: Device List window
wrapper.paragraph: You can define the population of robot controllers that the job should be applied to, using the Device List window. This window contains the metadata of all robot controllers that are part of the group.

listitem.paragraph: Network Address: This field is mandatory. IP address or DNS name of the controller. The controllers can be distributed on multiple subnets. You can add controllers that cannot be directly found by Netscan from the current location.
Controller Name: This is an optional field. This value is used to verify the controller name that can be identified by the network address.
System Name: This is an optional field. This value is used to verify the system name running on the controller that can be identified by the network address.
Group: This is an optional field. This value is used to filter out a subset of robot controllers from a list while executing jobs.
Subgroup: This is an optional field. This value is used to filter out a subset of robot controllers from a list while executing jobs.

Comments: This is an optional field. You can type in comments in this field. If you add a controller to the list using the Scan Subnet command, then the system displays Found by Netscan message in this field.

wrapper.title: Allow Execution State Running
wrapper.paragraph: You can not execute a job when the controller's program execution is in the Running state. This precaution is to avoid production getting disturbed when robots are performing sensitive path following applications such as laser cutting or arc welding.
Jobs such as backup or search RAPID data can put load on the controller. Select the Allow Execution State Running check box available in the Device Selection area while executing these jobs.

wrapper.title: Allow System Failure state
wrapper.paragraph: When the Allow System Failure state check-box is selected, the job will be executed even if the connected controller is in system failure state. When this check-box is not selected, the jobs will not be executed if the controller is in system failure state.

wrapper.title: Verify identity of OmniCore controllers
wrapper.paragraph:
Refer to
Operating manual Integrator's guide OmniCore
for details about certificate handling in OmniCore controllers. When the Verify identity of OmniCore controllers check-box is selected, the security certificate will be verified before executing the job.

wrapper.title: Supported actions
wrapper.paragraph: Using the Jobs feature, you can perform the following actions on a group of robot controllers. You must select the required action in the Selected Action list in the Jobs window. Some of these actions require the following additional data.
