Remote Start and Stop in Auto
A remote user with this grant can start and stop program in Auto mode.
Read files on remote mounted devices
A user with this grant have access to read files on a remote mounted device.
Read and write files on remote mounted devices
A user with this grant have access to read and write files on a remote mounted device.
A user with this grant can detach the FlexPendant in automatic mode without causing any stops. The hot swappable FlexPendant option is required.
Log off FlexPendant user when switching to Auto
A user with this grant is automatically logged off from the FlexPendant when switching from Manual mode to Auto mode.

wrapper.paragraph: Application grants are not supported in OmniCore systems.

wrapper.title: Adding a user to the Administrators group
wrapper.paragraph: The predefined user roles available in the robot controller are Administrator and Operator. For the Administrator role the controller grant UAS_ADMINISTRATION is enabled by default.

listitem.paragraph: On the Controller tab, click Add controller and then click Add Controller.. and then select the controller from the Add Controller dialog.
On the Controller tab, click Request Write Access.
Click Authenticate and then click Login as Different User. The Login dialog opens, enter the default credentials User Name and password as Admin and robotics respectively and click Login.
Click Authenticate and then click Edit User Accounts.
The Edit User Accounts window opens.
On the Users tab, click Add user.
Enter suitable values in the fields as required and then under Roles select the Administrator check box. Click Apply.
The new user gets added to the Users on this controller list.

wrapper.paragraph: Use the same steps to create users for various roles.

listitem.paragraph: In the Edit User Accounts, click the Roles tab.
On the Roles tab, click Add Role.
Enter the required details and click Apply.
The new role gets added to the selected user.
In the Edit User Accounts, click the Roles tab.
On the Roles tab, select the role and then click Edit User. Enter the required changes and click Apply.
In the Edit User Accounts, click the Users tab, and then click Add User.
In the User Name and Password boxes, enter suitable values. Select the required roles and then click Apply.
The new user gets added to the Users on this controller list with the selected roles.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: You can view events in the Event Log. The severity of each event is indicated by its background color; blue for information, yellow for warning and red for an error which needs to be corrected to proceed.
On the Controller tab in the Controller Tools group, click Events to view the Event Log.

td.paragraph: Events dealing with handling of the system.
Events dealing with system functions, system states, and so on.
Events dealing with system hardware, manipulators as well as controller hardware.
Events dealing with RAPID instructions, data, and so on.
Events dealing with the control of the manipulator movements and positioning.
Events dealing with inputs and outputs, data buses, and so on.
Application specific events, arc welding, spot welding, and so on.
Events dealing with the configuration of the system.
Connected Service Embedded event logs which are generated during starting, registering, unregistering, losing connectivity, and so on.

wrapper.title: Configuration configuration editor
wrapper.paragraph: From the Configuration you can view and edit the system parameters in a controller. The Configuration has a direct communication with the controller. This means that changes you make are applied to the controller as soon as you complete the action.
With the Configuration Editor, the following actions can be performed for each topic:

listitem.paragraph: view types, instances, and parameters
edit instances and its parameters
copy and paste instances within a type
add and delete instances

wrapper.title: Layout of the Configuration
wrapper.paragraph: The Configuration consists of the Type name list and the Instance list.
The Type name list displays all available configuration types for the selected topic. The list of type names can not be edited.
The Instance list displays all system parameters of the selected type in the Type name list. Each row in the list is an instance of the type. The columns show the parameters and their values.
The Configuration editor includes the following:

listitem.paragraph: Configuration topics
Communication
Controller
I/O
Man-machine communication
Motion
PROC
Add Signals
I/O Engineering Tool

wrapper.title: Add Signals
wrapper.paragraph: This is a special window to add several I/O signals at the same time. You need to have write access to the controller to be able to open the add signal window.

td.paragraph: Defines the name for one or more signals.
Defines the device to which the signal belongs.
Optionally, offers filtering and sorting based on this category.
Defines the number of signals to add in a range.
Defines the index (number) to start the range with.
Defines the number which the index should increase with.
Defines the bits in the I/O memory map of the assigned unit to which the signal is mapped.
Optionally, offer filtering and sorting based on this category.

Defines the write access to I/O signals for categories of I/O controlling clients connected to the robot controller. This field is enabled only when Advance check-box is selected. Not necessarily Write access. Options are Default, ReadOnly and All.
Specifies the I/O signal value to be used at the start.
Applies an inversion between the physical value of the signal and its logical representation in the system.

listitem.paragraph: To view the topics of a controller, from the Controller tab, expand the Configuration node for the controller.
All topics in are now displayed as child nodes to the Configuration node.
To view the types and instances of a topic, double-click the topic node for the topic to view.

The Configuration Editor is now opened, listing all types of the topic in the Type name list. In the Instance list, each instance of the selected type in the Type name list is displayed as a row. The parameter values of the instances are displayed in the columns of the instance list.
To view detailed parameter information for an instance, double-click the instance.
The instance editor now displays the current value, restrictions, and limits of each parameter in the instance.

wrapper.title: Editing parameters system parameters editing parameters
wrapper.paragraph: You can either edit the parameters of one single instance, or you can edit several instances at the same time.

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller tab, expand the Controller and the Configuration node and double-click the topic that contains the instances to edit.

wrapper.paragraph: This opens the Configuration Editor.

listitem.paragraph: In the Type name list of the Configuration Editor, select the type that the instance to edit belongs to.

wrapper.paragraph: The instances of the type are now displayed in the Instance list of the Configuration Editor.

listitem.paragraph: In the Instance list, select the instances to edit and press the Enter Key. To select several instances at once, hold down the SHIFT or CTRL key while selecting.
Alternatively, right-click an instance and then click Edit.

wrapper.paragraph: The Instance Editor is now displayed.

listitem.paragraph: In the Parameter list of the Instance Editor, select the parameter to edit and change the value of the parameter in the Value box.

When editing several instances at one time, the parameter values you specify will be applied to all instances. For parameters that you do not specify any new value, each instance will keep its existing value for that parameter.
Click OK to apply the changes to the configuration database in the controller.
For many parameters, the changes will not take effect until the controller is restarted. If your changes require a restart, you will be notified of this.
You have now updated the controller's system parameters. If you are going to make several changes, you can wait with the restart until all changes are done.

wrapper.title: Adding instances
wrapper.paragraph: With the Configuration Editor, you can select a type and create a new instance of it. For example, adding a new instance of the type Signal creates a new signal in the system.

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller tab, expand the Controller and the Configuration node and double-click the topic that contains the type of which you want to add an instance.

wrapper.paragraph: This opens the Configuration Editor.

listitem.paragraph: In the Type name list of the Configuration Editor, select the type of which you want to add an instance.
Right-click anywhere in the configuration editor or on the Type node and then select New Type from the context menu.
A new instance with default values is added and displayed in the Instance Editor window.
If required, edit the values.
Click OK to save the new instance.

wrapper.paragraph: The values in the new instance are now validated. If the values are valid, the instance is saved. Otherwise, you will be notified of which parameter values to correct.

listitem.paragraph: For many instances, the changes will not take effect until the controller is restarted. If your changes require a restart, you will be notified of this.

You have now updated the controller's system parameters. If the changes require a restart of the controller, the changes will not take effect until you do this. If you are going to make several changes, you can wait with the restart until all changes are done.
In the Controller tab, expand the Controller and the Configuration node and double-click the topic that contains the instance to copy.

wrapper.paragraph: This opens the Configuration Editor.

listitem.paragraph: In the Type name list of the Configuration Editor, select the type of which you want to copy an instance.
In the Instance list, select the instance to copy.
Right-click the instance to copy and then select Copy Type from the context menu.
Change the name of the new instance. If required, also edit the other parameter values.
Click OK to save the new instance.

wrapper.paragraph: The values in the new instance are now validated. If the values are valid, the instance is created. Otherwise, you will be notified of which parameter values to correct.

listitem.paragraph: For many instances, the changes will not take effect until the controller is restarted. If your changes require a restart, you will be notified of this.

You have now updated the controller's system parameters. If the changes require a restart of the controller, the changes will not take effect until you do this. If you are going to make several changes, you can wait with the restart until all changes are done.
In the Controller tab, expand the Controller and the Configuration node and double-click the topic that contains the type of which you want to delete an instance.

wrapper.paragraph: This opens the Configuration Editor.

listitem.paragraph: In the Type name list of the Configuration Editor, select the type of which you want to delete an instance.
In the Instance list, select the instance to delete.
Right-click the instance to delete and then select Delete Type from the context menu.
A message box is displayed, asking if you want to delete or keep the instance. Click Yes to confirm that you want to delete it.
For many instances, the changes will not take effect until the controller is restarted. If your changes require a restart, you will be notified of this.

You have now updated the controller's system parameters. If the changes require a restart of the controller, the changes will not take effect until you do this. If you are going to make several changes, you can wait with the restart until all changes are done.

wrapper.title: Save a configuration file
wrapper.paragraph: The system parameters of a configuration topic can be saved to a configuration file configuration file , stored on the PC or any of its network drives.
The configuration files can then be loaded into a controller. They are thereby useful as backups, or for transferring configurations from one controller to another.

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller tab, expand the Configuration node and select the topic to save to a file.
In the Controller tab click Save Parameters.
You can also right-click the topic and then select Save Parameters from the context menu.
In the Save As dialog box, browse for the folder to save the file in.
Click Save.
In the Controller tab, select the Configuration node, not any of its types.
In the Controller tab click Save System Parameters.
You can also right-click the Configuration node and then click Save Parameters.
In the Save System Parameters dialog box, select the topics to save to files. Then click Save.
In the Browse for Folder dialog box, browse for the folder to save the files in, and then click OK.

wrapper.paragraph: The selected topics will now be saved as configuration files with default names in the specified folder.

wrapper.title: Loading a configuration file
wrapper.paragraph: A configuration file contains the system parameters of a configuration topic. They are thereby useful as backups, or for transferring configurations from one controller to another.

When loading a configuration file on a controller, it must be of the same major version as the controller. For instance, you cannot load configuration files from an IRC 5 system to an OmniCore controller.

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller tab, select the Configuration node.
In the Controller tab click Load Parameters.
You can also right-click the configuration node and then select Load Parameters from the context menu.

wrapper.paragraph: This opens the Open dialog box.

listitem.paragraph: In the Open dialog, browse to the configuration file to load.
In the Open dialog box, select how you want to combine the instances in the configuration file to load with the existing in the controller:

td.paragraph: replace the entire topic with the contents in the file.
select Delete the existing topic and load instances
add new instances from the configuration file to the topic, without modifying the existing ones.
select Load if no existing instances

add new instances from the file to the topic and replace the existing ones with values from the file. Instances that only exist in the controller and not in the configuration file will not be changed at all.
Instances that exist in the controller will first be deleted and then loaded with values from the file, that is, it will get default values for parameters not listed in the file.
click Load and replace existing instances

listitem.paragraph: Click Open to load.
In the information box, click OK to confirm that you want to load the instances from the configuration file.

wrapper.paragraph: If a restart of the controller is necessary for the changes to take effect, you will be notified of this.

wrapper.title: Layout of the Instance editor configuration editor instance editor
wrapper.paragraph: The Instance Editor window lists the parameters and their values of the selected instance.
In the Value column you can view and edit the value of the parameters.
When you click a row, the lower section of the Instance Editor window displays the type of parameter, restrictions for the parameter value and other conditions for the parameter.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: FlexPendant Viewer is an add-in to RobotStudio that retrieves and displays a screenshot from the FlexPendant. The screenshot is generated automatically at the moment of the request.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The controller you want to retrieve screen shots from must be added to your robot view.
A FlexPendant must be connected to the controller. If no FlexPendant is currently connected (option Hot plug is installed and the jumper plug is used) then no screen shot can be retrieved.

listitem.paragraph: Make sure you are connected to the controller.
In the Controller Tools group, click the arrow next to the FlexPendant icon, and then click FlexPendant Viewer.
A screen shot will be displayed in the workspace.
To reload the screen shot, click Reload in the workspace.
To set an automatic reload period for the screen shot, click on the menu Tools, point to FlexPendant Viewer and click Configure.
Set the desired reload period and select the check-box Activated. Then click OK.

wrapper.title: Results on the controller
wrapper.paragraph: The screenshot will automatically be saved as a file on the controller. When a new request is sent, a new screenshot is generated and saved, overwriting the previous file.
No message will be displayed on the FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Select this option to view and edit various properties of the connected robot controller.

wrapper.title: Renaming the controller Properties Renaming the controller
wrapper.paragraph: The controller name is an identification of the controller that is independent of the system or the software running on the controller. Unlike the controller ID, the controller name does not have to be unique for each controller.
The controller name must be written with characters from the ISO 8859-1 (Latin 1) character set.

listitem.paragraph: In the Configuration group, click Properties, and then click Rename.
The Rename Controller dialog box appears.
Enter the new name of the controller in the dialog box.
Click OK.
The new name will be activated when the controller is restarted.
You will be prompted to either click Yes to restart the controller immediately or click No to restart later.

wrapper.title: Setting the controller date and time Properties Set date and time
wrapper.paragraph: You can either set the date and time to the same as the network time server, or you can specify the date and time manually.
Use this procedure to set the controller date and time:

listitem.paragraph: In the Configuration group, click Properties, and then click Date and Time.
The Set Date and Time dialog box appears.
This dialog provides two options: Network Time and Manual Time.
Select Network Time and in the Time server address box, enter the IP address of the network time server.
Select Manual time and then set the Date and Time in the boxes provided. You can select the required time zone in the Time zone list.

wrapper.title: Setting the Controller ID Properties Set controller ID
wrapper.paragraph: The Controller ID is by default set to the serial number of the controller. The Controller ID is a unique identifier for the controller and should not be changed. However, if the hard disk of the controller is replaced, the ID will be lost and you must set it back to the serial number of the controller.
You must Request Write Access to the controller before setting the controller ID.

listitem.paragraph: In the Configuration group, click Properties, and then click Controller ID.
The Set Controller ID dialog box appears.
Enter the Controller ID and then click OK.

wrapper.paragraph: Use only characters from the ISO 8859-1 (Latin 1) character set and no more than 40 characters.

wrapper.title: Configuring the public network interface of the controller

wrapper.paragraph: While connecting RobotStudio to the public network, IP address must be set only on the MGMT port for RobotWare 7.

listitem.paragraph: On the Controller tab, in the Configuration group, click Properties and click Network settings and then click Public Network.
Select Obtain an IP address automatically to set the controller to receive the IP address from the network's DHCP server.
OR
Select Use the following IP address and then enter the required IP address, Subnet Mask and Default Gateway boxes to manually set the IP address of the controller.
Click the Port Speed (Mbps) drop-down to select the port speed, this selection is only available for RobotWare 7.1 onwards.

Port speed has three options, Auto, 10, 100. When the port speed is set to Auto, the network switch and the network interface automatically finds the highest available supported speed and adapts to this port speed. The adapted maximum port speed will be displayed.
It is possible to set the DNS server address for the controller, write access to the controller is required to use the following procedure.
Select Automatically get DNS server address to set the controller to receive the DNS server address automatically.
OR
Select the Use the following server addresses and then enter the Preferred DNS server and Alternate DNS server and click Apply.

wrapper.title: Configuring the I/O network of the controller
wrapper.paragraph: The following procedure is applicable for RobotWare 7.4 onwards.

listitem.paragraph: On the Controller tab, in the Configuration group, click Properties and click Network settings and then click I/O Network.
Enter suitable values as required in the IP Address and Subnet Mask.
The value of the Default Gateway is retrieved from the public network interface of the controller, hence this is a read-only field.
Select the Port Speed (Mbps), and click Apply.

The actual port speed on the network interface may differ from the port speed selected in the Port Speed (Mbps) if the network switch does not support the selected speed. When the port speed is set to Auto, the network switch and the network interface automatically finds the highest available supported speed and adapts to this port speed.

wrapper.title: Viewing controller and system properties Properties View controller and system properties
wrapper.paragraph: You can view the following properties for a controller and its running system.

listitem.paragraph: In the Configuration group, click Properties, and then click Controller and System Properties.
The Controller and System Properties window appears.
In the tree view at the left of the window, browse to the node for which you want to view the properties.
The properties of the selected object are displayed in the Properties list to the right of the window.

wrapper.title: Viewing the Device Browser Properties Device Browser
wrapper.paragraph: The Device Browser device browser displays the properties and trends of the various hardware and software devices in a robot controller. To open the Device Browser, in the Configuration group, click Properties, and then click Device Browser.

wrapper.title: Displaying the properties of a device
wrapper.paragraph: In the tree view, browse to the node for which you want to view the properties and then click it. The properties of the selected object, along with their corresponding values, are listed to the right of the tree view.

wrapper.title: Updating the tree view
wrapper.paragraph: Press F5, to update the tree view.
Alternatively, right-click inside the tree view pane, and then click Refresh.

wrapper.title: Displaying a trend
wrapper.paragraph: Select a device in the tree view and then double-click any property, that has a numerical value, in the right-hand panel. This opens a trend view. The trend view collects data at a rate of one sample per second.

wrapper.title: Hiding, stopping, starting or clearing a trend
wrapper.paragraph: Right-click anywhere on the trend view and then click the required command.

wrapper.title: Saving system diagnostics Properties Save System Diagnostics
wrapper.paragraph: You can create a System Diagnostics data file from RobotStudio.
To save a System Diagnostics data file to your PC, in the Configuration group, click Properties, and then click Save system diagnostics.

wrapper.title: Manage Certificates
wrapper.paragraph: When connecting to an OmniCore controller, the communication is encrypted using certificates on the controller. By default, these are self-signed certificates that must be trusted by the RobotStudio user. In this case, the following dialog will be displayed.

To ensure a trusted connection, it is recommended to replace the certificates of the controller with the certificates that are trusted by the PCs, which will be connected to the controller. RobotStudio supports only PEM (.pem) certificate. Refer
Operating manual Integrator's guide OmniCore
for more information on supported certificate types.

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller tab, select Add Controller < Connect to Controller.
Select Request Write Access.
In the Configuration group, click Properties, and then click Manage Certificates.
In the Manage Certificates window, select the certificate to be replaced and select Replace certificate.

wrapper.paragraph: Select Restore to default if you want to restore the certificate that is generated by the controller.

listitem.paragraph: Browse for the certificate to be used and select Open.
Select Yes to clear the previous certificate and replace it with the selected certificate.

wrapper.title: Configure firewall
wrapper.paragraph: Use this feature to set up the firewall to allow network connections. When you choose Allow, it configures the firewall to allow connections through the public network port on the controller. To prevent connections press Block. Advanced button opens the Configuration editor to manually edit the configuration file. By default, the firewall will be blocked. This must be configured to allow network connection through WAN.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The most frequent RobotWare system update use case is updating one or more software, for example, RobotWare and add-ins. This is a frequent operation during the commissioning time, especially on large installations.
To perform a RobotWare system update, the controller must be in the RobotWare system mode.
System update changes the configuration of the currently installed RobotWare system. There are different types of configuration changes, such as:

listitem.paragraph: Adding or removing licenses
Upgrading, removing installed software or adding new software
Activating or deactivating optional features

wrapper.paragraph: Before performing a system update, it is recommended to:

listitem.paragraph: create a backup of the system (user data) and store it on an external storage media.
create a snapshot of the current system state.

wrapper.title: Upgrading a software in the RobotWare system
wrapper.paragraph: The following procedure provides the steps involved during the update of the RobotWare system.
Do not turn off the controller while system update is in progress. Doing this may in worst case lead to data corruption in the RobotWare system, in which case it needs to be reinstalled.

listitem.paragraph: Access the Modify Installation view in RobotStudio.
Select Software > Included.
The Included Software window displays the software that is included in the current RobotWare system.
Select the product that should be upgraded and tap Update.
In the Update Software window, select the software version to be used and tap OK.
The Summary tab shows an overview of all the changes.
Continue to modify the system, or select Apply/Apply and reset to confirm and save the changes.

wrapper.paragraph: The Modify Installation dialog will be closed during the controller update.

When the update process is finished, check the event log for information about the update results. A successful update will be indicated in the event log, and if the update has failed, one or more error logs will be generated.

wrapper.title: Adding/removing software
wrapper.paragraph: The following procedure provides the steps involved during the update of the RobotWare system.
Do not turn off the controller while system update is in progress. Doing this may in worst case lead to data corruption in the RobotWare system, in which case it needs to be reinstalled.

listitem.paragraph: Access the Modify Installation view in RobotStudio.
Select Software > Included.
The Included Software window displays the software that is included in the current RobotWare system. Select one of the following:
Select the product box for the software that should be added to the system.
Deselect the product box to remove the product from the system.

wrapper.paragraph: Products may have dependences to certain versions of other products. A product may only be removed if all products that are dependent on it are removed as well.

listitem.paragraph: The Summary tab shows an overview of all the changes.
Continue to modify the system, or select Apply/Apply and reset to confirm and save the changes.

wrapper.paragraph: The Modify Installation dialog will be closed during the controller update.

When the update process is finished, check the event log for information about the update results. A successful update will be indicated in the event log, and if the update has failed, one or more error logs will be generated.

wrapper.title: Adding/removing add-in packages
wrapper.paragraph: The following procedure provides the steps involved during the update of the RobotWare system.

Do not turn off the controller while system update is in progress. Doing this may in worst case lead to data corruption in the RobotWare system, in which case it needs to be reinstalled or recovered from a snapshot.

listitem.paragraph: Access the Modify Installation view in RobotStudio.
Select one of the following:
To add add-in packages, select Software > Available and tap Include.
To remove add-in packages, select Software > Included and tap Remove.

wrapper.paragraph: Products may have dependences to certain versions of other products. A product may only be removed if all products that are dependent on it are removed as well.
RobotWare is mandatory and cannot be removed from the system.

listitem.paragraph: The Summary tab shows an overview of all the changes.
Continue to modify the system, or select Apply/Apply and reset to confirm and save the changes.

wrapper.paragraph: The Modify Installation dialog will be closed during the controller update.

When the update process is finished, check the event log for information about the update results. A successful update will be indicated in the event log, and if the update has failed, one or more error logs will be generated.

wrapper.title: Changing the software installation order when adding/removing RobotWare add-ins
wrapper.paragraph: When adding and removing RobotWare add-ins to/from the system, sometimes it is necessary to manually adjust the installation and initialization order or the included add-ins.

listitem.paragraph: Access the Modify Installation view in RobotStudio.
Select Software > Included.

In the Included Software window, tap the Installation order button to open the Change Installation Order window. Select a product and use the up and down arrows to change the installation order. Select Done.
The Summary tab indicates that the installation order has been updated.
Continue to modify the system, or select Apply/Apply and reset to confirm and save the changes.

wrapper.paragraph: The Modify Installation dialog will be closed during the controller update.

When the update process is finished, check the event log for information about the update results. A successful update will be indicated in the event log, and if the update has failed, one or more error logs will be generated.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The following categories of system features can be updated:

listitem.paragraph: System options
Controllers
Robots
FlexPendant

wrapper.paragraph: Some features extend, showing more options upon selection. For example, in the group controller variant, you get the option of choosing variant type only when a controller first is selected. The additional drive units work similarly, some are unavailable until you select a different drive system type. This means options can be locked behind selections.
Do not turn off the controller while system update is in progress. Doing this may in worst case lead to data corruption in the RobotWare system, in which case it needs to be reinstalled.

listitem.paragraph: Access the Modify Installation view in RobotStudio.
Select the tab Options.
Select the option category to be updated, and the corresponding Options that should be activated/deactivated for the system.

wrapper.paragraph: Linked options will be selected automatically.
Conflicting options cannot be selected.

listitem.paragraph: The Summary tab shows an overview of all the changes.
Continue to modify the system, or select Apply/Apply and reset to confirm and save the changes.

wrapper.paragraph: The Modify Installation dialog will be closed during the controller update.

When the update process is finished, check the event log for information about the update results. A successful update will be indicated in the event log, and if the update has failed, one or more error logs will be generated.

wrapper.title: Adding licenses to enable additional option access

wrapper.paragraph: Do not turn off the controller while system update is in progress. Doing this may in worst case lead to data corruption in the RobotWare system, in which case it needs to be reinstalled.

listitem.paragraph: Access the Modify Installation view in RobotStudio.
Select the tab Options.
Select Edit to access the Edit License files window. Select one of the following:
Select Add to browse for a new license to be added.
Select an existing license and tap Remove.
The Summary tab shows an overview of all changes.
Continue to modify the system, or select Apply/Apply and reset to confirm and save the changes.

wrapper.paragraph: The Modify Installation dialog will be closed during the controller update.

When the update process is finished, check the event log for information about the update results. A successful update will be indicated in the event log, and if the update has failed, one or more error logs will be generated.
Do not turn off the controller while system update is in progress. Doing this may in worst case lead to data corruption in the RobotWare system, in which case it needs to be reinstalled.

listitem.paragraph: Access the Modify Installation view in RobotStudio.
Select the tab Options.
Select one of the following:
Select Export and browse to the location where the exported option selections should be saved. Select Save.
The current option selections will be saved to an RSF file that can be imported or added to other systems.
Select Import and browse to the location of the configuration file, and then select Open.

wrapper.paragraph: All current selections will first be cleared.

listitem.paragraph: Select Add and browse to the location of the configuration file, and then select Open.

wrapper.paragraph: Existing selections are kept, and options that are not currently selected will be added.

listitem.paragraph: Continue to modify the system, or select Apply/Apply and reset to confirm and save the changes.

wrapper.paragraph: The Modify Installation dialog will be closed during the controller update.

When the update process is finished, check the event log for information about the update results. A successful update will be indicated in the event log, and if the update has failed, one or more error logs will be generated.

wrapper.title: Drive system types
wrapper.paragraph: The following matrix describes the existing drive system types and some examples of compatible products:

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Before installing a new RobotWare system on the controller, it is required to:

listitem.paragraph: create a virtual controller.
create an installation package.
Start RobotStudio.
Select Add Controller > Connect to Controller in the Controller ribbon.
In the Connect to Controller window, select the Virtual Controllers tab.
Select New Controller.
In the New Virtual Controller dialog, select option Create New and complete the following:
Give the new system a valid name. If you enter an invalid name you will not be able to proceed.

wrapper.paragraph: The system name can contain between 1 to 55 characters. Allowed characters are "AâZ", "aâz", "0â9", and "-" (hyphen). Hyphen "-" is only allowed between characters.

Selecting option Create from backup can be used to create a system based on the configuration found in the selected Backup. This means that the same set of SW products (RobotWare and add-ins), licenses and options will be used.
Note, however that the software referred to by the Backup is not included in the Backup itself and must be previously downloaded to your computer by using the RobotStudio Add-Ins page.

Note also that this procedure will not automatically include RAPID programs and system parameters to your new system. If needed, they can be loaded to the new system by restoring the Backup once the new system is installed and started.

listitem.paragraph: Select OK to continue.
Continue with creating an installation package.

wrapper.title: Creating a new installation package
wrapper.paragraph: The installation package is a software package that consists of predefined directory structure and number of files, used for purpose of re-deploying RobotWare System on a robot controller. The installation package is created in RobotStudio and is deployed on the controller using RobotWare Installation Utilities on the FlexPendant.

RobotWare Installation Utilities is a small package of installation related utilities that is always present on each robot controller and cannot be removed. It is used to deploy and re-deploy RobotWare system which is the operating system of the robot controller. When in RobotWare Installation Utilities mode, the robot cannot be moved using the FlexPendant and robot programs cannot be written or executed.
The following prerequisites must be met before you can start creating an installation package:

listitem.paragraph: Latest version of RobotStudio must be installed.

License files for products to be installed must be available. Licenses are included in the RobotWare system at purchase, but can also be retrieved from a backup of the RobotWare system currently deployed on the controller, or exported from the controller via RobotWare Installation Utilities.

wrapper.paragraph: Virtual licenses can also be used.

listitem.paragraph: Product versions to be installed must be available in RobotStudio or in a custom location.

These versions can be made available by selecting a RobotWare distribution package (.rspak file) from RobotStudio (tap Install Package in the Add-Ins tab). All products that are installed this way, have matched versions and correct dependencies to each other.
A virtual controller must be created.
Start RobotStudio.
Select Add Controller > Connect to Controller in the Controller ribbon.
In the Connect to Controller window, select the controller and tap OK.
Request write access.
Launch the Modify Installation dialog from the Controller ribbon.
Select the tab Software.
Select Create Package to create an installation package based on the virtual controller configuration.

wrapper.paragraph: If the virtual system has been built using virtual licenses, these will not be included in the installation package.

If virtual licenses are used, the selected feature configuration will be matched against the real licenses present in the controller and the installation will stop if some licenses are missing. This situation can be avoided if real licenses from the controller are exported and imported into the virtual system when it is built.

listitem.paragraph: In the Create Installation Package dialog, define the following:
Enter a name for the installation package.
Browse and select the output folder (for example, a USB-stick) for the installation package.
Select OK.
The window Installation Package created is displayed. The installation package for the selected system has been created. Select OK.
Continue with installing the package on the controller.

wrapper.title: Introduction
wrapper.paragraph: The Conveyor Tracking tab contains a tree view browser displaying the connected DSQC2000 units and other related objects. It is used as a user interface to configure settings and monitor live signals of the DSQC2000 tracking units.

wrapper.title: Note
wrapper.paragraph:
While in the tree view browser or any of the related object dialogues, pressing F1 will open the
Application manual Conveyor tracking
.
To open the Conveyor Tracking tab:

td.paragraph: Click Conveyor Tracking from the Configuration group, in the Controller tab.

wrapper.paragraph: The Conveyor Tracking tab opens.

wrapper.title: Connecting a CTM
wrapper.paragraph: One of the following methods can be used to connect the CTM to the computer:

paragraph.bold: Connecting the CTM through a WAN port

listitem.paragraph: This method is recommended only after a fixed IP address is configured for the CTM - WAN interface.
Connect the computer with a fixed IP address to the same WAN network, through a network switch or a direct connection. Configure the computerâs IP address with the CTMâs subnet.
Example:
The default factory setting for WAN is Obtain an IP address automatically (DHCP client). To connect a WAN with this setting a DHCP server is required on the network.
This method is recommended for the initial setup of a CTM with default factory settings. It can also be used for debugging, when there is a connection problem with the CTM.
Configure the fixed IP address of the computer with the subnet of the CTM â LAN interface. The LAN interface has IP address 192.168.126.200.
Example:

wrapper.title: Adding a CTM
wrapper.paragraph: To add a CTM, a connection must be established between the computer and the CTM:

td.paragraph: The Add CTM dialog box displays all the detected CTMs.
Select the CTM from the list and click OK.

wrapper.paragraph: The CTM is added to the tree view object browser.

wrapper.title: Identifying a CTM in RobotStudio
wrapper.paragraph: If RobotStudio is connected to a network with multiple CTMs, it may become difficult to identify a particular CTM. This can be avoided by a direct connection via LAN port.
To simplify identification, it is recommended to assign a unique and descriptive name for every CTM.
One of the following methods can also be used to identify a CTM:

listitem.paragraph: Select the device in the tree view browser, its corresponding green discovery LED will start blinking on the CTM module.
Press the white SW1 button on the CTM module once, a green dot will start blinking on the corresponding CTM symbol in the tree view browser.

wrapper.paragraph: Do not press the SW1 button while the CTM is restarting, this will reset the CTM to default factory settings and any updates or upgrades will be lost.

wrapper.title: Network settings
wrapper.paragraph: The WAN port of the CTM is connected to the robot controllers through an Ethernet network. To establish communication between the robot controllers and the CTM, a fixed IP address must be assigned to the CTM. The IP address should be located on the same subnet as the network interface of the connected robot controllers.
To change the network settings:

td.paragraph: Right-click the CTM in the tree view browser, select Network settings, and then click WAN interface.
Enter the IP address, the Subnet mask, and the Default gateway (optional) and then click OK.

wrapper.title: Authenticate
wrapper.paragraph: A CTM has the following two predefined users:

td.paragraph: It is an advanced user and is used for advanced maintenance and troubleshooting.
It is a normal user and is used for everyday maintenance and troubleshooting.

wrapper.paragraph: Login as an advanced user to upgrade the firmware.

To use some features of a CTM, a login is required. If you are using the default credentials, login is automatic to the Conveyor Tracking tab. Otherwise, authentication is requested whenever required.
It is recommended to change the password to improve security.
Appropriate credentials are required to make any modifications to the CTM configuration and firmware.
You cannot recover a lost password, so ensure the password is not lost or forgotten.
To login as a user:

td.paragraph: Right-click the CTM and click Authenticate > Login as a Different User.
Enter the required credentials and click Login.

wrapper.paragraph: To log off the current user:

td.paragraph: Right-click the CTM and click Authenticate > Log Off.

wrapper.paragraph: To change the password of the current user:

td.paragraph: Right-click the CTM and click Authenticate > Change password.
Change the password and click OK.

wrapper.title: Rename
wrapper.paragraph: You can rename the CTM, the encoders, and the sensors.
To rename any object:

td.paragraph: Right-click the object in the tree view browser and then click Rename.

wrapper.paragraph: The Rename dialog box opens.

td.paragraph: Enter a new name for the object and then click OK.

wrapper.paragraph: The new names are stored in the CTM and will be displayed in RobotStudio, once it is restarted.

wrapper.title: Configuring an encoder
wrapper.paragraph: You can configure some settings of an encoder, for example, Speed filter.
To configure an encoder:

td.paragraph: Right-click the encoder in the tree view browser and then click Configure encoder.

wrapper.paragraph: The Configure encoder tab opens.

td.paragraph: Modify the settings and click Apply.

wrapper.paragraph: An encoder can be configured as used or not used. This change in configuration will affect how the encoder is displayed in the tree view browser. To tune the encoder speed filtering, you can define the Low-pass filter cut off frequency in the Speed filter section.

wrapper.title: Configuring a sensor
wrapper.paragraph: You can configure some settings of a sensor, for example, Sync Separation.
To configure a sensor:

td.paragraph: Right-click the sensor in the tree view browser and then click Configure sensor.

wrapper.paragraph: The Configure sensor dialog box opens.

td.paragraph: Modify the settings and click Apply.

wrapper.paragraph: Sync separation is used to filter an unstable signal in the sync input signal. It defines the minimum encoder distance (counts) between two sync pulses from the sensor. When the actual distance is shorter than this value, then the second sync pulse is ignored.
The sensor type can be configured as I/O Sensor, Camera, or Not used. This change in configuration will affect how the sensor is displayed in the tree view browser.

wrapper.title: Note
wrapper.paragraph: It is recommended to set the same sync separation value for all the encoders.
The camera pulse width defines the pulse length (ms) used with the camera trigger signal.

wrapper.title: Note
wrapper.paragraph: For high speed conveyors, the pulse length must be shorter than the time between consecutive camera images, so that:
Camera pulse width < (Trigger distance in mm / Max conveyor speed in mm/s) / 1000

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: A restart or reboot of a CTM can be performed using the tree view browser.

wrapper.title: Restart
wrapper.paragraph: A restart is required after modifying the settings of the CTM.
To restart the CTM:

td.paragraph: Right-click the desired CTM in the tree view browser and then click Restart.

wrapper.title: Reboot
wrapper.paragraph: A reboot is slower than a restart, it corresponds to the restart after cycling the power.
To reboot the CTM:

td.paragraph: Right-click the desired CTM in the tree view browser and then click Reboot.

wrapper.title: Signals
wrapper.paragraph: There are 3 types of live signals: encoder, sensor, and other. You can sort and filter the signals by various properties:

td.paragraph: Signal value type, for example, float
Signal value unit, for example, Hz
Signal category, for example, Public or Internal
Signal name used in the robot controller, for example, TrigVis
Connector on the CTM, for example, X11
Information on what the signal represents

wrapper.title: List all signals
wrapper.paragraph: To list all the signals:

td.paragraph: Right-click the desired CTM in the tree view browser and then click Signals.

wrapper.title: List all encoder signals
wrapper.paragraph: To list all the encoder signals:

td.paragraph: Right-click the desired encoder in the tree view browser and then click Signals.

wrapper.title: List all sensor signals
wrapper.paragraph: To list all the sensor signals:

td.paragraph: Right-click the desired sensor in the tree view browser and then click Signals.

wrapper.title: Backup and Restore
wrapper.paragraph: You can save a backup of the CTM settings. The backup will contain:

listitem.paragraph: Data about the CTM configurations, including encoder and sensor parameters and new names. While restoring the backup, these settings are applied to the target CTM
Network settings
Firmware version information

wrapper.title: Creating a backup of the CTM
wrapper.paragraph: Keeping a backup is recommended to simplify the task of replacing the CTM with a new unit.
To create a backup of the CTM:

td.paragraph: Right-click the CTM in the tree view browser and then select Create Backupâ¦ .

wrapper.paragraph: The Create Backup from CTM dialog box opens.

td.paragraph: Enter or select a save Location and click OK.

wrapper.paragraph: A backup of the CTM is created in the entered location.

wrapper.title: Restoring a backup
wrapper.paragraph: To restore a backup of the CTM:

td.paragraph: Right-click the CTM in the tree view browser and then select Restore Backupâ¦.

wrapper.paragraph: The Restore from Backup to CTM dialog box opens.

td.paragraph: Enter or browse to the required Location, select backup folder and click Open.

wrapper.paragraph: The backup of the CTM saved in the folder is displayed in the list of the Available backups section.

td.paragraph: Select the required backup from the list and click OK.

wrapper.paragraph: The CTMâs settings will be restored according to the backup, after a restart of the CTM.

wrapper.title: Firmware upgrade
wrapper.paragraph: A firmware upgrade is normally provided by ABB, as a .cab file.
It is recommended to backup the CTM configurations, as a firmware upgrade may result in the factory default network settings.
To upgrade the firmware of the CTM:

td.paragraph: Login as an advanced user to upgrade the firmware.
Right-click the CTM and then click Firmware Upgrade.

wrapper.paragraph: The Firmware Upgrade dialog box opens.
It displays the current version of the firmware.

td.paragraph: Click Browse, navigate to the .cab file and then click Open.

wrapper.paragraph: The Verify Software dialog box opens.
It displays the publisher of the file.

td.paragraph: If the publisher is trusted, click Yes.

wrapper.paragraph: The Firmware Upgrade dialog box opens.
It displays the new firmware version.

td.paragraph: Verify it and click Upgrade, to download it.

wrapper.paragraph: The CTM will restart after the download and installation.
After a firmware upgrade, you may have to restore the network settings of the CTM.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The Motion Configuration window contains functions for making and viewing advanced system configurations, such as changing controller and baseframe positions, calibrating and setting up external axes.
Editing the system may result in corrupted systems or unexpected robot behaviors. Be sure to understand the effects of the changes before proceeding.

wrapper.title: The mechanism folder node
wrapper.paragraph: The property page of this node contains controls for mapping and setting axis and joints. It is from this page you set up external axes.

wrapper.title: The mechanism library node
wrapper.paragraph: The property page of this node contains controls for changing the baseframe of the robot or mechanism. Here, too, you specify whether the baseframe is moved by another mechanism (coordinated motion), like a track external axis.

listitem.paragraph: Move the mechanical unit (robot or external axis) to its new location using the ordinary tools for moving and placing objects.
In the Controller browser, select the controller for the mechanical unit.
On the Controller tab, in the Virtual Controller group, click Motion Configuration.
This opens the Motion Configuration dialog.
Select the node for the mechanical unit in the hierarchical tree. The baseframe property sheet for the robot is now displayed.
Select the baseframe position values to use after restarting the robot.

td.paragraph: Reset all changes to the baseframe made since the last time the virtual controller was started.

paragraph.bold: Stored Station Values System Configuration stored station values

td.paragraph: Reset all changes made to the baseframe since the last time the station was saved.
Optionally, you can enter new values in the baseframe coordinate boxes (relative to the controller world coordinate system).
Read and use the current location of the baseframe.
Optionally, you can enter new values in the baseframe coordinate boxes (relative to the controller world coordinate system).

listitem.paragraph: Click OK.

wrapper.title: Calibrating the baseframe position
wrapper.paragraph: The station with a virtual controller that includes a workpiece positioner which is based on backup from a robot controller. RobotStudio needs to take the calibration of the workpiece positioner into account, otherwise the positioner will be misplaced. The calibration parameter for a mechanism can be used to take the calibration of the real positioner into account.

The positioner mechanism is placed according to the base frame values of the virtual controller. When a virtual controller is created from backup, in which, the positioner was calibrated online using four points method, and if the positioner was not in its sync position at the first calibration point, then the positioner mechanism will not be aligned with the system's task frame.
You can calibrate base frame values to realign the positioner mechanism with the system's task frame.

listitem.paragraph: In the controller tab, click Motion Configuration. The Motion Configuration dialog opens.
In the Motion Configuration window, select the positioner mechanism and then click Calibrate.
The Base Frame Calibration Position dialog opens.
From the Motion Configuration dialog, copy the Orientation values under Base Frame and paste these values in the boxes under Orientation in the Base Frame Calibration Position dialog.
Click Apply and then click OK. You must restart the controller when prompted. The positioner mechanism will be aligned with the system's task frame now.
Any object attached to the positioner will take the orientation of the positioner.
On the Controller tab, in the Virtual Controller group, click Task Frames.
The Modify Task Frames dialog box appears.
Set the reference to World, UCS, or Local.
Edit the position and orientation of task frames in the Task Frames coordinate box.
Click Apply.
To the question, Do you also want to move the Base Frame(s)?
Click Yes to move the base frame, but keeps its relative placement to the task frame.
The related robot will move in relation with the station world, but since the robot moves with the task frame, the robot base frame values remain unchanged.

Click No. The following question appears Do you want to update the controller configuration and restart?. Click Yes to restart the controller and update the base frame configuration of the connected virtual controller.

The related robot will not move in relation with the station world. Here the task frame has moved, hence the base frame values will be recalculated. The controller must be restarted for the configuration changes to take place.

wrapper.paragraph: If there are any stationary RAPID objects (tooldata, workobjects) connected to the robot, the following question appears Do you want to keep the positioning of all stationary RAPID objects?

listitem.paragraph: Click Yes to keep all the stationary RAPID objects in their global coordinates.
Stationary workobject and tooldata will remain constant in relation to the station world but their values will be recalculated.
Click No to move all the stationary RAPID objects along with the base frame (same coordinates relative to base frame).
Stationary workobject and tooldata will move with the robot and its values will not be recalculated.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The main purpose of this feature is to create a new station with a VC similar to the connected robot controller. This helps a robot technician to work offline even when the robot controller is disconnected.

listitem.paragraph: Connect the PC to a robot controller.
On the Controller tab, click Request Write Access.
Click Go Offline.
The Go Offline dialog box is displayed.
Enter a name in the Virtual Controller Name field and browse for the location to save the system.
Select the RobotWare version followed by the RobotWare Add-in version and click OK.
A new station gets created with a virtual controller which has the same configuration as the robot controller.

wrapper.paragraph: A pre-requisite is that any RobotWare add-ins used by the system must be available on the PC. A Relation is automatically created between the virtual controller and the robot controller.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The transfer function allows easy transfer of offline-created RAPID programs to the real robot on the shop floor. This means that you can transfer data from a virtual controller (which is offline) to a robot controller (which is online). As part of the transfer function you can also compare the data present in the virtual controller with that present in the robot controller and then select which data to transfer.
You can also use the transfer function to transfer data from a virtual controller to another virtual controller.

wrapper.title: Relations for transfer of data
wrapper.paragraph:
To transfer data, you must first set up a Relation Relation
between the two controllers. A Relation defines the rules for the transfer of data between the two controllers.

wrapper.title: Creating a Relation
wrapper.paragraph: When you have two controllers listed in the Controller browser, you can create a Relation between them. To create a Relation:

listitem.paragraph: On the Controller tab, in the Transfer group, click Create Relation.
The Create Relation dialog box is displayed.
Enter a Relation Name for the relation.
Specify the First Controller, from the list.
The First Controller, also called the Source, owns the data being transferred.
Specify the Second Controller, from the list. This can either be a robot controller or another virtual controller.
The Second Controller, also called the Target, receives the data being transferred.
Click OK.
The relation between the controllers is now created.

wrapper.paragraph: After this, the Relation dialog box opens, using which you can configure and execute the transfer. Relations of a controller are listed under its Relations node in the Controller browser.
The properties of the relation are saved in a XML file under INTERNAL in the owner controllerâs system folder.

wrapper.title: Transferring data
wrapper.paragraph: You can configure the details of the transfer of data and also execute the transfer, in the Relation dialog box.
To open the Relation dialog box, double-click a relation. Alternatively, select a relation in the Controller browser, and then in the Transfer group, click Open Relation.

wrapper.title: Configuring the transfer
wrapper.paragraph: Before executing a transfer, you can configure the data to be transferred, under the Transfer Configuration heading. Configure using these guidelines:

listitem.paragraph: Use the check boxes in the Included column to include or exclude the corresponding items shown in the tree structure. All items in a module that are included will be transferred. Other non-listed items of a module such as comments, records and so on will be automatically included in the transfer.
The Action column shows a preview of the transferâs result, based on the items you include or exclude.

If a module exists both in the source and the target controllers, and the Action column shows Update , then click Compare in the Analyze column. This opens the Compare box which shows two versions of the module in different panes. The affected lines are highlighted and you can also step through the changes. You can choose one of the following options for the comparison:
Source with target - Compares the source module with the target module
Source with result - Compares the source module with the module that will be the result of the transfer operation
BASE (module), wobjdata and tooldata are excluded by default.
wobjdata wobj0, tooldata tool0, and loaddata load0 of the BASE module are unavailable for inclusion.

wrapper.paragraph: A task can be transferred only if:

listitem.paragraph: Write access to the target controller is present (must be manually retrieved).
Tasks are not running.
Program execution is in the stopped state.

wrapper.title: Executing the transfer
wrapper.paragraph: After you have configured the transfer, you can execute it.

Under the Transfer heading, the Source and Target modules are shown along with the arrow showing the direction of the transfer. You can change the direction of the transfer by clicking Change Direction. This also switches the source and target modules.

To execute the transfer click Transfer now. A dialog showing a summary of the transfer appears. Click Yes to complete the transfer. The result of the transfer is displayed for each module in the output window.
The Transfer now button is disabled if:

listitem.paragraph: None of the included tasks can be transferred.
Write access is required but not held.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This feature allows you to remotely monitor the robot connected to a real controller. It displays a 3D layout of the connected robot controller and enhances userâs current perception of reality by adding motion visualization augmentation.

The Online Monitor shows TCP robots and TCP robots with track. When connecting the Online Monitor to a virtual controller, the motion is shown only if the virtual controller is using Free-Run mode, not the Time Slice mode.

wrapper.title: Using Online Monitor
wrapper.paragraph: The following procedure describes the Online Monitor feature in RobotStudio:

listitem.paragraph: Connect the PC to a controller and add the controller.
Click Online Monitor.
The 3D view of the mechanical units of the controller system is displayed in the graphics window.

wrapper.paragraph: The robot view is refreshed every second with the current joint values of all the mechanical units.

wrapper.title: Gravity parameters in online monitor
wrapper.paragraph: Online Monitor displays the orientation of a robot according to its gravity parameters. The Gravity Alpha, Gravity Beta and Gamma Rotation parameters define the rotation of the robot around the X, Y and Z axis in the world coordinate system. The Online Monitor orients the robot in the Graphical view according to the gravity parameters.

These parameters describe how the robot is oriented in relation with the floor or ground, whether it is suspended (mounted on the ceiling), shelf mounted (mounted on the wall), or mounted on the regular floor. If the robot is configured to be mounted on the ceiling, it will be displayed upside down in the Online Monitor. You can set these parameters in the Motion configuration file.
For more information about gravity parameters, see Technical reference manual System parameters

wrapper.title: Indication of TCP
wrapper.paragraph: A cone is automatically created to indicate the active tool data being used. The cone has its base in the robot wrist and its tip at the location of the tool data.

wrapper.title: Kinematic Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: When the Kinematic Limitation button is enabled, the graphical 3D viewer indicates whether the robot is at a joint limit or at a singularity.

For joint limits, the corresponding link is highlighted in yellow to indicate a warning and in red to indicate an error. The tolerance limits are defined in RobotStudio Options - Online - Online Monitor.
For singularity, a markup indicates when the axis 5 is close to singularity. The singularity level is also defined in RobotStudio Options.

wrapper.title: Visualizing Safety Zones in Online Monitor
wrapper.paragraph: This feature lets you to visualize the current status of the manipulators in a robot system and provides an augmented reality of the robot cell. It allows you to visualize a failure scenario, for example, an unplanned stopping of a robot. To give the user an idea of the physical layout and the safety zone that has caused this stopping of the robot, safety zones are visualized in online monitor. When the robot enters a restricted zone, the safemove supervision feature stops the robot.
Features

listitem.paragraph: A Show Safety Zones button is available in the Online Monitor for each manipulator in the system, for example, four buttons in a MultiMove system with four manipulators.
The name of each tool zone and the corresponding manipulator is shown as a markup, for example, Rob1 STZ1, â¦, Rob4 STZ8, Rob1 MTZ1, â¦, Rob4 MTZ8 and so on.
Zones that are defined as Allow inside are visualized as a green semitransparent hollow shape.
Zones that are defined as Allow outside are visualized as a red semitransparent solid shape.
A message is displayed in the output window if no STZ or MTZ is defined for the manipulator.
The controller event log message 20468 SC STZ violation is displayed in the output window if it is present in the controller event log.

wrapper.paragraph: You can open one SafeMove Configurator at a time, even though several controllers may be connected. If the SafeMove Configurator is opened for one controller, real or virtual, the icon gets disabled for the other controllers.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: To synchronize is to make sure that the RAPID program in the virtual controller corresponds to the program in the station. You can synchronize from the station to the virtual controller and vice versa.

In a station, a robotâs position corresponds to the targets and its movements are defined by move instructions in the robot path. These correspond to data declarations and instructions in the modules of the RAPID program.

wrapper.title: Synchronizing to RAPID
wrapper.paragraph: This operation updates the RAPID program of the virtual controller to reflect the latest changes in the station. Perform this operation before running a simulation, saving a program to file and before taking a backup of a virtual controller.

listitem.paragraph: To synchronize, click the arrow next to the Synchronize icon, and then click Synchronize to RAPID.
Select the elements to be synchronized from the list.

td.paragraph: Specifies the target module of the virtual controller, if it does not exist , it will be created.
Select from the list of modules or type in the name of the new module.
Specifies whether the data must be created as LOCAL. Adds the keywork LOCAL before the data declaration and creates data LOCAL to the module.
Specifies the storage type of the data declaration.
Specifies whether the data declaration must be declared as inline or named. In this case the data is declared in the instruction itself.

listitem.paragraph: Click OK.
The message Synchronization to RAPID completed is displayed in the Output window.

wrapper.paragraph: To see the properties of targets , the containing path must be expanded.
Any reference to workobjects or tooldata from an instruction will be synchronized even if they are not selected.

wrapper.title: Synchronizing to the station
wrapper.paragraph: This operation updates the station to reflect the latest changes of the RAPID code in the virtual controller. Perform this operation when you start a virtual controller with RAPID program, when you have loaded a program or module from a file, or after editing a program.
To synchronize to station, click the arrow next to the Synchronize icon, and then click Synchronize to Station.

Select the objects to be synchronized to the station from the list. It is not possible to change the properties in this step. For changing any of the following properties the RAPID code must be edited.
Click OK. The message Synchronization to Station completed is displayed in the Output window.

wrapper.title: Synchronize to and from files
wrapper.paragraph: RAPID can be synchronized from the files of the HOME folder as an alternative. This option is available only in the context menu of the selected file.

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller browser, under Home folder, right-click any RAPID module and then click Synchronize to Station to synchronize the selected file to the station.
In the Controller browser, under Home folder, right-click a RAPID module and then click Synchronize to File to match the station into the selected file.
Robtargets that are local to a procedure are not supported by Synchronize to Station. Only robtargets that are local to a module are supported.

RobotStudio does not fully support instructions using Offs or RelTool functions. These are synchronized and will appear in the element browser, but commands such as View Tool at Target and Locate Target will not work. Targets used in the instructions will not be visible in graphics. However, instructions can be programmed and edited using the RAPID Editor and can be simulated using the virtual controller.
RobotStudio does not support RAPID programs containing arrays of tooldata, robtargets and workobjects. These programs will not be synchronized to the station.

Workobjects and tooldata that are shared between several tasks must be specified in RAPID with its full value for each task when programming offline with RobotStudio. This will trigger a warning Initial value for PERS not updated in the controller event log. You may ignore this warning. However, you must carefully ensure that the RAPID variable definitions are the same in all tasks, otherwise you may get unexpected behavior.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: The Adjust Robtargets feature helps in recalculating and changing the robtarget data (tooldata and workobject data) while maintaining the joint angles of the robot. The robtarget data related to the specified source tooldata and workobject will be adjusted for usage with the new tooldata and workobject. In the RAPID tab, in the Controller group, click Adjust Robtargets to access this feature.

listitem.paragraph: You should have a controller (virtual or robot) running with one or more modules containing procedures with a sequence of move instructions expressed with a defined tool and workobject.
You should have RobotStudio Premium license to use this feature.
The Execute button of the feature Adjust Robtargets will be enabled only if the selected tool data or workobject data have the same properties, such as robhold, ufprog, ufmec and so on.

wrapper.paragraph: Arrays, event records, and offsets are not supported. Relative tool is also not supported. Circular move instruction (MoveC) is supported.

wrapper.title: Using Adjust Robtargets

wrapper.paragraph: Take a backup copy of your modules before adjusting your robtargets.
The following procedure describes the Adjust Robtargets feature in RobotStudio:

listitem.paragraph: On the RAPID tab, in the Controller browser, select a RAPID task or module under the RAPID icon. Then click Adjust Robtargets on the RAPID tab.
Alternatively, right-click the RAPID task or module in the Controller browser, and then click Adjust Robtargets in the context menu.
The Robtarget Adjust dialog box appears.

wrapper.paragraph: You can access Adjust Robtargets from the Controller tab also. Right-click the RAPID task or module in the Controller browser and then click Adjust Robtargets in the context menu.

listitem.paragraph: If the module you want to adjust is selected, then go to Step 4. Otherwise continue with the next step.
Select a task from the Task drop-down list and module from the Module drop-down list.

wrapper.paragraph: In the Module drop-down list, you can either select a particular module or <ALL> to update.

listitem.paragraph: Select the source robtarget data (that is, the data defined in the selected task) from Old tooldata and Old wobjdata drop-down list.
Select the destination robtarget data (that is, new tooldata and workobject) from New tooldata and New wobjdata drop-down list.
Click Execute.
The Execute button is enabled only if source robtarget data (that is, old tooldata and workobject) and destination robtarget data (that is, new tooldata and workobject) are different.

wrapper.paragraph: The module searches for move instructions that use the specified old tooldata or workobject and recalculates the robtarget data for the new tooldata and workobject.
For example,

listitem.paragraph: Select "tool0" as the source tool and "wobj0" as the source workobject.
Select "toolb" as the new tool and "wobjb"as the new workobject.
Click Execute.

wrapper.paragraph: Robtargets of "tool0" and "wobj0" will be replaced with re-calculated robtargets which correspond to the same robot configuration (all joint angles will be the same), and with the new tool "toolb" and "wobjb". Note that both the tooldata and the wobjdata are replaced independently.

wrapper.title: Update instruction
wrapper.paragraph: By default, the Update instruction check box is selected. This means that move instructions using the specified source (old) tooldata and workobject will be updated to use the target (new) tooldata and workobject in addition to recalculating the robtargets.
If the Update instruction check box is cleared, the robtargets will be recalculated, but the move instructions will not be updated. They will still use the source tooldata and workobject.

This feature is useful after the calibration of tooldata and workobject. After calibration, you might still want to use the old names of the tooldata and workobject, but update their values and recalculate the robtargets accordingly. The following sample procedure illustrates how this can be accomplished.

wrapper.title: Sample procedure
wrapper.paragraph: Prerequisite: RAPID module with robtargets and move instructions that use uncalibrated tooldata tool1, and workobject wobj1.

listitem.paragraph: Calibrate your tooldata tool1, and workobject wobj1. Store the new values in tool1_calib and wobj1_calib, respectively. Keep the old values of the uncalibrated tooldata and workobject in tool1, and wobj1. An error message gets displayed for an invalid selection of tooldata or workobject data.

Open the Adjust robtargets tool and clear the Update instruction check box. Select your RAPID module, enter tool1, and wobj1 as your old tooldata and wobjdata, and tool1_calib, and wobj1_calib as the new tooldata and wobjdata, respectively.
Click Execute, and apply the changes to the controller from the RAPID Editor
In the RAPID Editor, rename your tooldata tool1 to tool1_uncalib, and tool1_calib to tool1 and apply the changes to the controller. Also, perform the same for wobj1.

wrapper.paragraph: Now, your robtargets are updated to match the calibrated values of tool1 and wobj1.

listitem.paragraph: If a robtarget is used more than once but with different tools or workobjects, then a message Target is referenced is displayed in the output window.

The adjust robtargets function operates on a module level and does not update any referenced targets defined in other modules. It ignores the scope of the robtargets when the referenced targets are local to a procedure. In this case, any targets with the same name in the module scope will also be updated.

Adjust Robtargets function works for modules with semantic errors, the editor excludes the particular line containing the error and continues with program execution. But Syntax errors stop program execution.
